Description: THIS PROJECT IS A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE NORTHEAST SEA GRANT PROGRAMS, THE NORTHEAST FISHERIES SCIENCE CENTER, AND THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT OFFICE.  NEW HAMPSHIRE SEA GRANT WILL BE CONDUCTING A REGIONAL RESEARCH COMPETITION THAT WILL PROVIDE HUMAN-DIMENSIONS RESEARCH OUTCOMES THAT CAN INFORM EMERGING POLICY AND DECISION-MAKING THAT WILL SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES, WORKING WATERFRONTS AND RESILIENCE COASTAL COMMUNITIES DURING THE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION PROCESS FOR OFFSHORE WIND DEVELOPMENT IN THE NORTHEAST.

PURPOSE: AMERICAN LOBSTER SUPPORTS THE MOST VALUABLE FISHERY IN THE UNITED STATES AND IS ECONOMICALLY VITAL AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT TO MANY COASTAL COMMUNITIES, PARTICULARLY IN RURAL AREAS OF MAINE. THE FISHERY OPERATES IN A RAPIDLY CHANGING ECOSYSTEM, IN WHICH WARMING ENHANCED GROWTH OF THE LOBSTER POPULATION IN THE GULF OF MAINE DURING THE 2000S AND 2010S, WHILE CONTRIBUTING TO A SUBSTANTIAL DECLINE IN THE SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND LOBSTER POPULATION AS CRITICAL TEMPERATURE THRESHOLDS WERE REGULARLY EXCEEDED. DISTINCT OCEANOGRAPHIC, ECOSYSTEM, AND LOBSTER POPULATION REGIMES HAVE BEEN CHARACTERIZED, YET RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THESE REGIMES HAVE NOT BEEN ANALYZED TO UNDERSTAND HOW BROADER ECOSYSTEM CONDITIONS MAY BE DRIVING SHIFTS IN LOBSTER POPULATIONS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE AUTHORS WILL DEVELOP A DEEP ANALYSIS OF REGIME SHIFTS IN THE NORTHEAST SHELF AND COASTAL MAINE ECOSYSTEMS TO UNDERSTAND 1) HOW CHANGES IN LOBSTER POPULATIONS ALIGN WITH AND ARE RELATED

PURPOSE: ALTHOUGH THE CURRENT LOBSTER STOCK ASSESSMENT MODEL IS ROBUST IN ITS ABILITY TO DETERMINE OVERFISHED STOCK STATUS IN LIGHT OF CLIMATE CHANGE, ACCURACY OF ASSESSMENT ESTIMATES AND FORECASTS WILL ULTIMATELY RELY ON THE QUALITY OF GROWTH INPUTS TO THE MODEL. THE AUTHORS PROPOSE TO ENHANCE AND APPLY A COMPREHENSIVE LOBSTER GROWTH MODEL THAT A) INTEGRATES MULTIPLE DATA SETS AND DATA TYPES IN A SYNTHETIC MODELING FRAMEWORK ACROSS JUVENILE AND ADULT LIFE STAGES, AND B) INCORPORATES EFFECTS OF CHANGING WATER TEMPERATURE IN ORDER TO GENERATE EXPANDED, TIME-VARYING GROWTH TRANSITION MATRICES (GTMS) FOR THE GULF OF MAINE/GEORGES BANK AND SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND (GOM/GBK AND SNE) STOCKS. THIS WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED COOPERATIVELY WITH THE ASMFC'S AMERICAN LOBSTER TECHNICAL COMMITTEE AND STOCK ASSESSMENT SUBCOMMITTEE AND WILL DIRECTLY SUPPORT THE 2025 AMERICAN LOBSTER BENCHMARK STOCK ASSESSMENT. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE RESEARCH CONDUCTED AS PART OF THE CINAR FEL

PURPOSE:  IN HAWAI'I AND OTHER U.S.-AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS (USAPI), INTENSE URBAN, RESIDENTIAL, INDUSTRIAL, AND MILITARY DEVELOPMENT ALONG A NARROW STRIP OF COASTAL LAND RESULTS IN A SUITE OF CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN (CECS) BEING RELEASED AND TRANSPORTED INTO GROUNDWATER AND NEARSHORE REEF ECOSYSTEMS, BUT THE IMPACTS REMAIN UNDERSTUDIED. THE PROJECT'S THREE OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) SUPPORT RESEARCH AND MONITORING THAT BUILD KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND IMPACTS OF CECS, 2) FOSTER COLLABORATIONS AND ENGAGE IN SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIPS WITH STATE AGENCIES, AND 3) ENHANCE CULTURAL AWARENESS AND ENGAGEMENT WITH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE PARTNERSHIP COORDINATION, EDUCATION, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND A REGIONAL COMPETED RESEARCH PROGRAM THAT ADDRESSES CECS IN THE COMMUNITIES AND COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS OF THE INSULAR PACIFIC, A VAST GEOGRAPHIC AND CULTURALLY DIVERSE AREA WITH INDIGENOUS AND HISTORICALLY MARGINA

PURPOSE: THE INTENDED PROJECT WILL AIM TO DEVELOP A CORAL REEF COMMUNITY MODEL FRAMEWORK TO INVESTIGATE REEFS AS SOCIAL-ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS WITH A FOCUS ON CORAL REEF FISHERIES. THE PRIMARY AIMS OF THIS STUDY ARE TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF VARIOUS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ON IMPORTANT FUNCTIONAL GUILDS WITHIN THIS ECOSYSTEM AND TO RECONSTRUCT HISTORICAL DYNAMICS OF A REEF SYSTEM IN HAWAI I. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TO CONSTRUCT AN ECOSYSTEM MODEL TO EXPLORE HISTORICAL REEF DYNAMICS IN HAWAI I, (2) EVALUATE ECOLOGICAL CHANGES ASSOCIATED WITH PROJECTED CLIMATE CONDITIONS, AND (3) QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF CONTEMPORARY AND INDIGENOUS MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS ON THE SYSTEM. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DEVELOPED FRAMEWORK WILL REPRESENT AN INNOVATIVE TOOL TO INFORM DECISION-MAKING THAT IS NOVEL IN ITS ABILITY TO PREDICT ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY INTEGRATING CONTEMPORARY AND INDIGENOUS MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. PURPOSE: THIS STUDY AIMS TO UPDATE ASSESSMENT METHODS TO MEET THE GOALS OF NOAA'S STRATEGIC PLAN FOR CLIMATE-READY FISHERIES AND ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT BY INTEGRATING AN EMERGING SUITE OF ASSESSMENT METHODS TO DEVELOP AN OPERATIONAL FRAMEWORK. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS STUDY WILL 1) LINK TRAWL SURVEY DATA WITH UNDERUTILIZED DATA IN SPATIOTEMPORAL MEDALS TO IDENTIFY PERSISTENT SEASONAL AND ANNUAL PATTERNS IN ABUNDANCE TRENDS TO HELP INFORM STOCK SUBPOPULATIONS/PUTATIVE GROUPS 2) QUANTIFY DISPERSAL BETWEEN GROUPS WITH (A) TAGGING DATA THAT EXTEND THE APPLICANTS SPATIOTEMPORAL MODELS TO ASSESS MOVEMENT OF MIGRATING ADULTS OVER SEASONAL AND ANNUAL SCALES; AND (B) ANALYSES OF GENETIC CONNECTIVITY USING SIBSHIP RECONSTRUCTION WAN QUANTIFICATION OF GENETIC VARIATION BETWEEN PUTATIVE GROUPS AND 3) EVALUATE WHETHER SPECIFYING A SINGLE STOCK OR MULTIPLE SUBPOPULATIONS ALTERS PERCEPTIONS OF PRODUCTIVITY AND STABILITY USING AGE-STRUCTURED POPULATION MODEL SIMULATIONS. PURPOSE: THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ADVANCE ECOSYSTEM BASED FISHERIES MANAGEMENT FOR GEORGES BANK BY QUANTIFYING TRADEOFFS ASSOCIATED WITH CANDIDATE MANAGEMENT POLICIES THROUGH MANAGEMENT STRATEGY EVALUATION. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS STUDY WILL UTILIZE A MULTISPECIES MODEL OF GEORGES BANK AS AN OPERATING MODEL IN A MANAGEMENT STRATEGY EVALUATION TO QUANTIFY DIRECT AND INDIRECT IMPACTS OF PORTFOLIO MANAGEMENT COMPARED TO SINGLE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PROVIDE A MULTISPECIES OPERATING MODEL AND SIMULATION TESTING TO COMPLEMENT THE PORTFOLIO PROJECT; ADVANCE THE SCIENCE OF EBFM IN THE NEW ENGLAND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT REGION, AND PROVIDE A CASE STUDY FOR OTHER FISHERIES CONSIDERING MANAGEMENT ADVICE FROM MULTISPECIES MODELS OR MSE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: NEW ENGLAND FISHERIES MANAGERS IN THE GEORGES BANK REGION AND OTHER FISHERIES MANAGERS CONSIDERING MULTISPECIES MODELS WHO CAN USE THIS WORK AS A CASE STUDY. PURPOSE: THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY ARE TO (1) RELATE PRE-HATCH CONDITIONS TO NSNA SIZE-AT-HATCH AND EXAMINE INFLUENCES OF SIZE-AT-HATCH ON NSNA LARVAL MORTALITY, (2) IDENTIFY THE PREFERRED PREY OF NSNA LARVAE AND RELATE PREFERRED PREY AVAILABILITY AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS TO NSNA LARVAL GROWTH, (3) MODEL SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN THE ABUNDANCE OF NSNA LARVAE AND THE ABUNDANCE OF THEIR PREFERRED PREY USING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, AND (4) HINDCAST NSNA SIZE-AT-HATCH AND LARVAL GROWTH AND RELATE HINDCASTED SIZE-AT-HATCH AND GROWTH TO FLUCTUATIONS IN NSNA AGE-1 ABUNDANCE DURING 2006-2023. KNOWLEDGE OF THE MECHANISTIC RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND NSNA RECRUITMENT GAINED THROUGH THIS RESEARCH WILL IMPROVE PREDICTION OF NSNA POPULATION FLUCTUATIONS, ALLOWING ANTICIPATION OF THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THIS STOCK. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FISH LARVAE WILL BE COLLECTED BIWEEKLY (MAY-AUG) TO MONTHLY (AUG-MAY) USING SURFACE AND DEPTH-STRATIF

PURPOSE: SPECIFICALLY, THIS WORK WILL DEMONSTRATE HOW TO BETTER INCORPORATE SPATIOTEMPORAL PATTERNS IN WEIGHT AT AGE, ACKNOWLEDGE THE EFFECTS OF DATA SAMPLING PROCESSES ON THE WEIGHT-AT-AGE MATRIX, AND EXPLORE HOW THESE CHANGES WILL IMPROVE ESTIMATES OF SPAWNING BIOMASS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE STUDY WILL EXAMINE HOW SPATIOTEMPORAL VARIABILITY AND TRENDS IN WEIGHT-AT-AGE DATA CAN BE INCORPORATED IN THE COMPOSITION OF WEIGHT AT AGE MATRICES AND THE EFFECTS OF THOSE DECISIONS ON STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND THE QUANTITIES RELEVANT TO MANAGERS, USING PACIFIC HAKE AS A CASE STUDY. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL GIVE INSIGHT INTO THE BEST PRACTICES OF INCORPORATING SPATIOTEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN GROWTH WITHIN STOCK ASSESSMENTS.CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE VARIABILITY IN GROWTH AND OTHER KEY VITAL RATES, AND SO ACCOUNTING FOR THIS VARIABILITY WITHIN DATA SOURCES AND STOCK ASSESSMENTS CAN PROVIDE ROBUST INFORMATION FOR CLIMATE-RESILIENT FISHERIES MANAGERS. PURPOSE: THE PRIMARY GOALS OF THIS STUDY ARE TO 1) ESTIMATE THE IMPACT OF THE U.S. SIMP ON IMPORT PRICE 2) ESTIMATE THE IMPACT OF THE 2018-2019 TARIFF DISPUTE WITH CHINA ON EXPORT PRICE AND TRADE DIVERSION, AND 3) ESTIMATE THE DISTRIBUTIONAL IMPACTS OF THIS TARIFF DISPUTE ON EX-VESSEL REVENUES AND OTHER FISHERY METRICS. ON EX-VESSEL REVENUES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE STUDENT WILL USE DIFFERENCE -IN-DIFFERENCE-IN-DIFFERENCE (DIDID) METHODS TO ESTIMATE IMPACTS OF THE 2017 U.S. SEAFOOD IMPORT AND MONITORING PROGRAM (SIMP) ON PRICES OF IMPORTED PRIORITIZED PRODUCTS. THEN USE THE DIFFERENCE-IN-DIFFERENCE METHODS TO ESTIMATE IMPACTS OF INCREASED TARIFFS ON EXPORT VALUES AND EX-VESSEL REVENUE. THEY WILL INVESTIGATE THE DISTRIBUTIONAL IMPLICATIONS OF THESE TARIFFS BY SPLITTING SAMPLES BASED ON CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING VESSEL SIZE, CATCHER-PROCESSOR VS. CATCHER VESSELS, VESSEL HOME PORT AND LOCAL VS. NON-ALASKA OWNERSHIP TO UNDERSTAND CHANGES TO FISHERY METRICS INCLUDING REVENUE, EFFORT

PURPOSE: THE OBJECTIVE OF MY RESEARCH IS TO EXPLORE HOW CLIMATE CHANGE, MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND BIOCULTURAL RESTORATION AFFECT FISH POPULATIONS AND FISHERIES HARVEST IN THE INDO-PACIFIC USING SIMULATION MODELING TECHNIQUES ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE STUDY WILL EXPLORE HOW TO MAXIMIZE FISH POPULATION RECOVERY AND NEARSHORE FISHERIES HARVEST ON O'AHU, HAWAI I UNDER A CHANGING CLIMATE. SECOND, THEY WILL INVESTIGATE HOW THE RESTORATION OF A TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN AQUACULTURE SYSTEM AFFECTS THE ECOSYSTEM DYNAMICS OF K NE OHE BAY, O'AHU, HAWAI I. FINALLY, THEYI WILL PROJECT PRIORITY FISHERY SPECIES BIOMASS TO INFORM THE JURISDICTIONAL FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR A CLIMATE CHANGE HOTSPOT: GUAM, MARIANAS ISLANDS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE INTENDED OUTCOMES OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROMOTE THE COORDINATION OF FEDERAL AND JURISDICTIONAL FISHERIES MANAGEMENT THROUGH INTEGRATING NUMEROUS DATA SOURCES AND COLLABORATING WITH MULTIPLE AGENCIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: RESOURCE MANAGERS AND INDIGE

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THE STUDY WILL BE TO USE HISTORICAL MARK-RECOVERY DATA TO INVESTIGATE MOVEMENT RATES OF ANTARCTIC BLUE WHALES AND MAKE INFERENCE ABOUT THEIR POPULATION STRUCTURE IN THE SOUTHERN OCEAN. SPECIFICALLY, TO DEEPEN UNDERSTANDING OF BLUE WHALE POPULATION DYNAMICS AND BALEEN WHALE DEMOGRAPHY, INFORM MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR FUTURE NMFS REVIEWS OF BLUE WHALES AND OTHER DEPLETED WHALE SPECIES. THE STUDY WILL THEN AIM TO INVESTIGATE 1) MODEL FETAL SEX RATIOS ACROSS THE GREAT WHALES (BALEEN AND SPERM WHALES) AND INVESTIGATE TRENDS IN RELATIONSHIP TO THEORIES OF ADAPTIVE SEX

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO CONTINUE A BAROTRAUMA REDUCTION PROGRAM DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED DURING THE FY 2020 2023 PERIOD THOUGH THE FY 2024 2027 PERIOD AS PART OF POST-DEEPWATER HORIZON OIL SPILL FISHERIES RESTORATION EFFORTS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROGRAM BLENDS SCIENCE, MARKETING, AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH AN INTERACTIVE ON LINE LEARNING PLATFORM AND THE DISTRIBUTION OF FREE FISH DESCENDING GEAR TO INSPIRE AND EMPOWER ANGLERS TO TAKE AN ACTIVE AND LASTING ROLE IN SUSTAINING GULF OF MEXICO REEF FISH RESOURCES. UF/FLORIDA SEA GRANT WILL PROVIDE: A COMMUNICATIONS MANAGER TO SERVE AS PRINCIPAL PROGRAM PLANNER, ORGANIZER AND REPORTING AGENT; A MARKETING SERVICES MANAGER TO SUPPORT WEBSITE MANAGEMENT, GRAPHIC DESIGN AND OUTREACH PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT, DIGITAL AND SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENT DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION, MARKET PLACEMENT AND PROGRAM ADVERTISING, AND OVERSIGHT OF THE PROCUREMENT, WAREHOUSING AND SHIPPING OF FISH DESCENDING DEVICES; AND

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING TO GUAM SEA GRANT IN ORDER TO BETTER UNDERSTAND COASTAL COMMUNITIES' PERCEPTIONS AND ATTITUDES REGARDING TRANSITIONING TO RENEWABLE ENERGY.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A COMMUNITY WIDE ONLINE SURVEY WILL BE LAUNCHED TO GATHER RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS REGARDING THEIR KNOWLEDGE, PERCEPTION AND ACCEPTANCE OF THIS TYPE OF ENERGY. THE GOAL IS TO HAVE 400 COMPLETED SURVEYS FROM WHICH TO EXTRACT THE DATA. PRIOR TO LAUNCHING THE SURVEY, AN ADVISORY BOARD COMPRISING OF 20-30 ENERGY LEADERS FROM GUAM AS WELL AS STAKEHOLDERS THAT MIGHT BE AFFECTED BY THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS OCEAN ENERGY (FISHERMEN, BOAT OPERATORS, TOURISM INDUSTRY, OCEAN-RELATED BUSINESSES, RESEARCHERS ETC) WILL BE CONSULTED ON HOW TO DESIGN THE SURVEY, WILL PRE-SCREEN POTENTIAL SURVEY QUESTIONS AND PROVIDE SUGGESTIONS ON HOW THE SURVEY COULD BE IMPROVED. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO ALASKA SEA GRANT TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING AND APPROPRIATE RESOURCES GOING TO RURAL ALASKA COMMUNITIES FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY. THIS PROJECT, A CLIMATE READY WORKFORCE FOR COASTAL ALASKA, WILL EVALUATE PROGRAMS AVAILABLE ACROSS ALASKA TO ASSESS THE NECESSARY QUALIFICATIONS FOR MAINTAINING RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEMS AND AVAILABLE TECHNICAL TRAINING PROGRAMS, MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ADDITIONAL TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES, WHERE THE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES SHOULD BE LOCATED TO ENSURE A LOCALLY RESOURCED WORKFORCE, AND POTENTIAL FUNDING SOURCES TO BUILD TRAINING PROGRAMS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO CO-CREATE EXTENSION MATERIALS WITH PARTNERS FOR COMMUNITIES TO UNDERSTAND THE VARIOUS RENEWABLE ENERGY OPTIONS THAT CAN MEET THE CHALLENGES OF ALASKA'S DIVERSE ENVIRONMENT. THE GOAL IS A CLIMATE-READY WORKFORCE LOCALLY SOURCED, SERVING THE COMMUNITIES WHERE THESE WORKERS RESIDE, WHO EARN HIGH-PAYING JOBS LOCALLY IN RURAL COMMUNITIES IN ALASKA.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO HAWAII SEA GRANT TO BETTER UNDERSTAND COMMUNITY NEEDS AND PERSPECTIVES ON RENEWABLE ENERGY TRANSITIONS. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP INFORMATION PATHWAYS AND TRUSTED RELATIONSHIPS THROUGH RECIPROCAL KNOWLEDGE TRANSFER AND TO SUPPORT COMMUNITY-BASED ENERGY PLANNING TO UNLOCK OCEAN ENERGY DEVELOPMENT. THE THREE MAIN ELEMENTS OF THE PROJECT ARE: (1) EXPANSION OF THE EXISTING HSEO ENERGIZE K KOU COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROGRAM TO INCLUDE OCEAN ENERGY AND RURAL COMMUNITIES, (2) FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND PROFESSIONALIZATION OF THE HSEO CLEAN ENERGY WAYFINDERS OUTREACH PROGRAM, AND (3) CAPACITY BUILDING FOR COMMUNITY AND LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO DIRECTLY ENGAGE WITH UNDER-SERVED COMMUNITIES TO SUPPORT ENERGY TRANSITION ENGAGEMENT AND DISCUSSIONS. THESE DISCUSSIONS WILL INCLUDE ASSESSING WHETHER A COMMUNITY IS WELL-SUITED FOR AND INTERESTED IN FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF AN OCEAN-ENERGY FOCUSED, COMMUNITY-BASED RENEWABLE ENERGY (CBRE) PROJECT. PURPOSE: ALASKA'S SEAFOOD INDUSTRY IS THE LARGEST EMPLOYER IN THE STATE AND SUPPORTS SUSTAINABLE JOBS IN COMMUNITIES SPREAD ALONG A COASTLINE OVER SIX-THOUSAND MILES IN LENGTH. RURAL RESIDENTS DEPEND ON ACCESS TO FISHERIES IN COMMUNITIES WITH LIMITED ALTERNATIVES FOR EMPLOYMENT OR INCOME. LIMITED ACCESS PROGRAMS, IMPLEMENTED IN ALASKA'S FISHERIES IN THE LATE 70S THROUGH 1990S, SECURED MANAGEMENT IMPROVEMENT BUT ALSO INCREASED THE COST OF ENTRY. THE COST BARRIER TO ENTRY HAS, IN TURN CONTRIBUTED TO THE DECLINE IN LOCAL PERMIT OWNERSHIP AND A "GRAYING OF THE FLEET" WITH FEWER YOUNG PEOPLE FROM ALASKA'S RURAL COMMUNITIES ENTERING THE FISHERIES. THE AK ON-BOARD COMMERCIAL FISHERMAN TRAINING PROJECT (AK ON-BOARD) WILL COMBINE EXPERTISE AND TRIED-AND-TRUE TRAINING METHODS FROM PROGRAMS LED BY ALASKA SEA GRANT, THE ALASKA LONGLINE FISHERMEN'S ASSOCIATION, THE ALASKA MARINE CONSERVATION COUNCIL, AND THE ALASKA MARINE SAFETY EDUCATION ASSOCIATION, TO PROVIDE REGIONAL TRAINING

PURPOSE: THIS REGIONAL, COLLABORATIVE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE YOUNG FISHERMEN IN NEW ENGLAND WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO RECEIVE CRITICAL VOCATIONAL TRAINING AS THEY ENTER THE INDUSTRY, DEVELOP INTO COMPETENT DECKHANDS, AND TRANSITION TO THE WHEELHOUSE AS CAPTAINS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: OVER THE LAST FEW YEARS, EACH PROJECT PARTNER DEVELOPED A SUCCESSFUL, BUT RELATIVELY NEW, TRAINING PROGRAM THAT TRAINS A YOUNG FISHERMAN THROUGH ONE OF THEIR EARLY CAREER STAGES. PARTNERS IN RHODE ISLAND ARE TRAINING NEW ENTRANTS, PARTNERS IN MASSACHUSETTS ARE TRAINING UNDER-SKILLED DECKHANDS, AND PARTNERS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE ARE TRAINING NEW CAPTAINS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THESE PARTNERS WILL COLLABORATE TO EXPAND THEIR TRAINING PROGRAMS SO THAT FISHERMEN IN EACH STATE HAVE ACCESS TO EACH STAGE OF TRAINING. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM AND COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH THE FISHING INDUSTRY ARE CRITICAL FOR DEVELOPING AN ADAPTIVE, SCALABLE, AND TRANSFERRABLE FRAMEWORK MODEL THAT CAN BE REPLIC

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DESIGN A COMMUNITY COLLEGE AQUACULTURE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT CERTIFICATE PROGRAM (WITH CREDITS TRANSFERABLE TO AN ASSOCIATE'S DEGREE) TO HELP TO READY THE SAN DIEGO REGION, AND SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA MORE GENERALLY, FOR A GROWING AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY. ESTABLISH AN AQUACULTURE PROGRAM ADVISORY COMMITTEE (AQUAPAC) CONSISTING OF AQUACULTURE INTERESTS AND MIRACOSTA FACULTY, LEADERSHIP AND STAFF TO INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT AND, EVENTUALLY IMPLEMENTATION AND SUSTAINABILITY, OF THE PROGRAM AND TRAINING FACILITY. 2. INDUSTRY TRAINING PRIORITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT. THE PRIORITY TRAINING NEEDS OF THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY IN THE REGION WILL BE DOCUMENTED, INCLUDING THE TOPICS, KNOWLEDGE STANDARDS, AND SKILL COMPETENCIES NEEDED FOR ENTRY LEVEL STAFF MEMBERS. 3. WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM SWOT (STRENGTHS, WEAKNESSES, OPPORTUNITIES, THREATS) ANALYSIS. AN ASSESSMENT OF AVAILABLE AND MISSING RESOURCE

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO REVIVE A PREVIOUSLY SUCCESSFUL CREW TRAINING PROGRAM BY UPDATING IT TO REFLECT CURRENT INDUSTRY NEEDS AND ADDING A MANAGER TRAINING COMPONENT TO EQUIP EMPLOYERS WITH THE NECESSARY TOOLS FOR RECRUITING AND RETAINING A NEXT-GENERATION WORKFORCE. PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CREATE A COMMERCIAL FISHING AND AQUACULTURE TRAINING PROGRAM IN MCCLELLANVILLE, SC TO SERVE THE SOUTHEASTERN USA REGION, AND DIRECTLY BUILDS OFF OF TWO PREVIOUSLY FUNDED "FOOD FROM THE SEA" SEA GRANT CAREERS PROJECTS.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CO-DEVELOPING A CURRICULUM PLAN WITH A PROGRAM STEERING COMMITTEE; CONDUCTING RECRUITMENT OF TRAINEES; IMPLEMENTING A COMMERCIAL FISHING AND AQUACULTURE TRAINING PROGRAM; AND CONDUCTING A THOROUGH EVALUATION OF THE PILOT PROGRAM TO FACILITATE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT AND INCORPORATION OF LESSONS LEARNED FOR SECOND ROUND AND FUTURE ITERATIONS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:  1. ENHANCED PROFESSIONALIZATION OF THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES COMMERCIAL FISHING WORKFORCE'S NEXT GENERATION 2. MCCLELLANVILLE BECOMES A REGIONAL HUB FOR COMMERCIAL FISHING WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT 3. MCCLELLANVILLE FURTHER SITUATES ITSELF TO PRESERVE ITS COMMERCIAL FISHING HERITAGE 4. ENHANCED CAPACITY OF SEAFO

ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROGRAM WILL CONSIST OF A TRAINING PHASE CONSISTING OF ONLINE AND IN PERSON TRAINING FOR THE INTERN COHORT, FOLLOWED BY A PERIOD OF SHORT EXPERIENCES WITH A VARIETY OF SHELLFISH FARM OR RELATED BUSINESS TO GIVE INTERNS A FEEL FOR THE INDUSTRY. FOLLOWING TRAINING INTERNS WOULD BE HIRED BY INTERESTED BUSINESS AND THE PROGRAM WOULD OVERALL ENTER AN EVALUATION PHASE AS TO THE EFFICACY IN IMPROVING WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT FOR SHELLFISH AQUACULTURE IN MA. PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PREPARE THE NEXT GENERATION OF AQUACULTURE FARMERS AND SUPPORTING SECTORS BY ESTABLISHING MORE TRANSPARENT, COMPREHENSIVE, AND ACCESSIBLE PATHWAYS FOR POST-SECONDARY AQUACULTURE EDUCATION AND TRAINING IN CONNECTICUT.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  ACTIVITIES WILL CONSIST OF PERFORMING A NEEDS ASSESSMENT FOR AQUACULTURE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN CT AND OUTREACH AND EDUCATION.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES:  -EDUCATION AND SKILLS ACQUIRED BY AQUACULTURE STUDENTS MATCH THE NEEDS OF THE CONNECTICUT AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY -IMPROVED CLASSROOM AND HANDS-ON TRAINING EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS OF ALL ABILITIES -A CLEAR PATHWAY FOR POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION IN AQUACULTURE IN CT THAT IS DEPICTED ON A NEWLY CREATED CT AQUACULTURE EDUCATION WEB PORTAL -IMPROVED STUDENT RETENTION WITH A GREATER NUMBER OF STUDENTS REMAINING IN CT TO PURSUE POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION, TRAINING AND EMPLOYMENT IN THE FIELD OF AQUACULTURE -A BETTER PREPARED AND TRAINED NEXT GENERATION CONNECTICUT

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO INCREASE PARTICIPATION AND SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF A DIVERSE AQUACULTURE WORKFORCE BY PROVIDING INTERNSHIP, TRAINING, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES IN HAWAI I AND THE PACIFIC REGION TO SUPPORT AQUACULTURE AND SEAFOOD SECTOR NEEDS OF THESE COMMUNITIES. ACCORDING TO A STUDY FROM NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY, THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY TWO TROPICAL CYCLONES THAT AFFECT NORTH CAROLINA EACH YEAR (HURRICANE STATISTICS, N.D.). WITHIN NC COASTAL COUNTIES, 6-27% OF PEOPLE LIVE BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY LINE IN EACH COUNTY (EANES, 2020). CLIMATE DISASTERS EXACERBATE EXISTING INEQUITIES AND CAN PUSH STRUGGLING PEOPLE FURTHER INTO THE MARGINS. 10% OF NORTH CAROLINIANS ARE LATINO; HOWEVER, MANY HEALTH DEPARTMENTS DO NOT HAVE APPROPRIATE CULTURAL COMPETENCY, SPANISH-SPEAKING STAFF, OR THE ABILITY TO SEND OUT EMERGENCY ALERTS IN LANGUAGES OTHER THAN ENGLISH (TIPPETT, 2021). PURPOSE: MARINE DEBRIS AUDITS SUGGEST THAT SINGLE USE FOOD PACKAGING CONTINUES TO GENERATE A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF MARINE DEBRIS, AND THAT SHARE IS ONLY PROJECTED TO GROW WITH THE POPULARITY OF CONVENIENCE AND TAKE OUT FOODS. IF LARGE-SCALE SHIFTS IN OUR PACKAGING MATERIALS, REUSE OF FOOD SERVING SYSTEMS, AND REPLACEMENTS FOR SINGLE-USE PLASTICS CAN BE ACCOMPLISHED, THEN THE INFLOW OF PLASTICS COULD BE REDUCED ON A GLOBAL SCALE. LIGNOCELLULOSE AND BIO-SOURCED MATERIALS ARE SUSTAINABLE, SAFE FOR FOOD PACKAGING, CAN OFTEN BE RECYCLED, AND BREAK DOWN TO BENIGN SUBSTANCES IN THE ENVIRONMENT. HOWEVER, THE PERFORMANCE AND COST OFTEN DO NOT MATCH UP TO PETROLEUM DERIVED PLASTICS. PUBLIC CONSUMER AND INDUSTRY ACCEPTANCE OF THESE NOVEL SOLUTIONS, LIFE CYCLE ANALYSIS, AND TECHNICAL-ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF THE PROCESSES WILL BE CONDUCTED. THE GOAL IS TO LOWER THE BARRIERS FOR COMPANIES TO ENTER THE SUSTAINABLE PACKAGING MARKET, AND UNDERSTAND SLOW RESOURCE LOOPS THAT HELP REDUCE THE INFLOW OF PLAST

PURPOSE: RECENT STUDIES HAVE IDENTIFIED RIVERINE SYSTEMS AS A KEY TRANSPORTATION VECTOR FOR MICROPLASTICS, BOTH INTO BROADER AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS AND DRINKING WATER SOURCES. THIS IS BECAUSE MICROPLASTICS ARE OFTEN EMITTED INTO RIVERINE SYSTEMS THROUGH STORMWATER SURGES, URBAN RUNOFF, AND WASTEWATER TREATMENT EFFLUENTS. HOWEVER, DESPITE BEING AWARE OF THE ROLE OF RIVERS AND EFFLUENTS IN THE TRANSPORTATION AND CONCENTRATION OF MICROPLASTICS, THERE IS LITTLE TO NO EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE CURRENTLY IN PLACE TO SEQUESTER AQUATIC MICROPLASTIC POLLUTANTS. THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO PIONEER EFFORTS TO ADVANCE AND PILOT NEW AQUATIC FILTRATION TECHNOLOGY DESIGNED TO MONITOR AND SEQUESTER AQUATIC MICROPLASTICS FROM RIVERINE ENVIRONMENTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: SPECIFICALLY, THE PROPOSAL AIMS TO FULFILL THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT OFFICE'S PRIORITY TO INVESTIGATE AND PREVENT THE ADVERSE EFFECTS OF MARINE DEBRIS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF RIVERINE INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE REMOVAL OF AQUATIC MICROPLASTIC

PURPOSE: MATERIALS EMPLOYED IN CRITICAL COASTAL ECONOMIC SECTORS ARE DOMINATED BY PLASTICS, CONTRIBUTING TO AN EVER-INCREASING MARINE DEBRIS PROBLEM. THREE KEY COASTAL SECTORS (AQUACULTURE, RESTORATION, AND WATER QUALITY PROTECTION) VITAL TO ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ARE OF PARTICULAR CONCERN DUE TO THEIR LOCATION WITHIN ECOLOGICALLY SENSITIVE AND PHYSICALLY HARSH ENVIRONMENTS, RAPID ECONOMIC AND POPULATION GROWTH, AND INHERENT RELIANCE ON HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS. NATURAL MATERIALS (E.G., COIR, JUTE, WATTLE, WOOD, HEMP) HAVE A LONG HISTORY OF TRADITIONAL USE IN THESE SECTORS, BUT HAVE BEEN DISPLACED BY NON-BIODEGRADABLE PROPRIETARY ALTERNATIVES (I.E., PLASTICS AND POLYMER COMPOSITES) THAT ACCUMULATE AND PERSIST IN MARINE AND ESTUARINE ENVIRONMENTS. THE NEED FOR NEW APPROACHES BLENDING TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE WITH MODERN ENGINEERING HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED IN THE MARINE DEBRIS ACT OF 2006 AS AMENDED. PURPOSE: LARGE MASSES OF DERELICT FISHING GEAR (DFG) ACCUMULATE ON CORAL REEFS AND SHORELINES ACROSS THE HAWAIIAN ARCHIPELAGO AND AROUND THE WORLD. INDIVIDUAL NET MASSES HAVE BEEN KNOWN TO WEIGH UP TO 11 TONS EACH AND POSE A DANGEROUS AND LETHAL THREAT TO ALL MANNER OF WILDLIFE, ENACT SEVERE HARM TO CORAL REEFS AND OTHER MARINE AND COASTAL SUBSTRATES, AND POSE A HAZARD TO NAVIGATION. THE LARGE VOLUME AND MASS OF MANY OF THESE DERELICT FISHING NETS AND OTHER GHOST GEAR MAKES WHOLESALE REMOVAL IN ONE PIECE VERY DIFFICULT AND OFTEN IMPOSSIBLE TO ACHIEVE SAFELY. PURPOSE: MICROPLASTIC POLLUTION IS A QUICKLY ESCALATING THREAT TO MARINE ECOSYSTEMS, AND RECENT STUDIES SHOW THAT STORMWATER RUNOFF TRANSPORTS THE BULK OF TERRESTRIAL MICROPLASTIC TO THE SEA. SOLVING THIS ENVIRONMENTAL CRISIS THROUGH UPSTREAM SOURCE CONTROL AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE WILL TAKE DECADES; THUS IMMEDIATE INTERCEPTION TECHNOLOGIES ARE NEEDED DESPERATELY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT PUSHES THE BOUNDARIES OF ON-GOING PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT ACTIVITIES AND TECHNOLOGIES ORIGINALLY DESIGNED TO CAPTURE SEDIMENT AND LARGER MARINE DEBRIS, AND CONDUCTS THE FIRST OF ITS KIND RESEARCH TO INVESTIGATE AND DEMONSTRATE WHETHER THESE ACTIVITIES CAN EFFICIENTLY ALSO CAPTURE MICROPLASTICS AND HOW TO INNOVATE TO IMPROVE CAPTURE OF MICROPLASTICS FROM STORMWATER RUNOFF. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT TEAM PROPOSES TO ADDRESS THE SEVEN OBJECTIVES LISTED BELOW (RESPONSIBLE PARTIES ARE NOTED IN PARENTHESES). PURPOSE: PLASTIC OCEAN WASTE (POW) IS ACCUMULATING IN OUR OCEANS AND ON OUR BEACHES AT AN ACCELERATING RATE. EIGHT MILLION METRIC TONS (8M MT) OF PLASTIC IS ENTERING THE WORLD'S OCEANS EACH YEAR (JAMBECK ET AL. 2015). THIS IS A RATE OF 1 TON PER MINUTE (AGENDA 2016). POW IS ACCUMULATING ANNUALLY ON ALASKA'S SHORELINES AT 34,500 MT TO 51,700 MT (70 MILLION TO 104 MILLION LBS.). THERE IS A NEED TO FIND IMPROVED METHODS OF ASSESSING, COLLECTING, AND UTILIZING POW TO ADDRESS THIS GROWING PROBLEM. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE TEAM PROPOSES TO EXPAND THE PILOT DEMONSTRATION OF A MOBILE PLASTIC OCEAN WASTE RECYCLING SYSTEM FROM THREE COASTAL COMMUNITIES TO FIVE COMMUNITIES OVER A TWO-YEAR PILOT DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM. THIS PROGRAM WILL LEVERAGE FUNDING FROM THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) AND U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA) SMALL BUSINESS INNOVATION RESEARCH (SBIR) PROGRAMS, AS WELL AS FUNDING FROM THE NOAA MARINE DEBRIS PROGRAM. PURPOSE: LOBSTER BUOYS ARE A STEADY PRESENCE IN HARBORS AND COASTAL WATERS ALONG MAINE'S EXTENSIVE SHORELINE. BOATERS CONTRIBUTE TO DERELICT FISHING GEAR ACCUMULATION AND OTHER MARINE DEBRIS. THIS RESULTS IN LOSSES TO THE LOBSTER INDUSTRY, AS WELL AS ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS TO VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES SUCH AS THE SPARSELY POPULATED OR INHABITED ISLANDS THAT LACK THE CAPACITY AND RESOURCES TO MITIGATE MARINE DEBRIS. MARINE DEBRIS IS CHALLENGING TO REMOVE DUE TO THE MANY SMALL, UNINHABITED ISLANDS WITH RUGGED LEDGES AND NO REASONABLE ACCESS TO SAFELY LAND A BOAT. PURPOSE: THE OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC SAFETY BY PREVENTING DROWNING DEATHS DUE TO RIP CURRENTS. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON PROVIDING A RIP CURRENT DETECTION TOOL DIRECTLY IN THE HANDS OF BEACHGOERS VIA A SMARTPHONE APP. USERS WILL SIMPLY POINT THE PHONE'S CAMERA TO THE WATER TO CHECK THE PRESENCE AND LOCATION OF RIPS. THE APP WILL ALSO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT RIP CURRENTS BY PROVIDING IN-APP
INFORMATION/LINKS TO EXISTING AND PLANNED VIDEOS THAT EXPLAIN THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF RIPS, HOW THEY FORM, AND HOW TO IDENTIFY THEM. 
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE INVESTIGATORS WILL COLLECT TRAINING/TESTING DATA OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF RIP CURRENTS, DEVELOP A MACHINE LEARNING (ML) MODEL TO DETECT DIFFERENT TYPES OF RIPS, AND OPTIMIZE THE MODEL FOR A SMARTPHONE PLATFORM. THE TEAM WILL COLLECT AND PRODUCE EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS ABOUT RIP CURRENTS AND PERFORM COMMUNITY OUTREACH FOR BETA TESTING USERS (LIFEGUARDS, SURFERS, AND OTHER KNOWLEDGEABLE USERS).
EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE APP WILL SEEK TO ENGAGE USERS AS CITIZEN SCIENTISTS WHEN THEY SHARE INFORMATION (DATE, TIME, LOCATION) ABOUT DETECTED RIPS. THESE DATA CAN BE USED TO HELP IMPROVE THE EXISTING NOAA RIP CURRENT FORECAST MODEL.
INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE KEY BENEFIT OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS ENHANCING PUBLIC SAFETY BY EDUCATING BEACHGOERS ABOUT RIP CURRENTS AND HOW TO IDENTIFY THEM. IT ALSO BENEFITS COASTAL COMMUNITIES TO ENSURE THE SAFETY OF THEIR VISITORS AND TO IMPROVE LOCAL TOURISM. LIFEGUARD OPERATIONS CAN BENEFIT IN TERMS OF EFFICIENCY IN PLANNING AND SCHEDULING LIMITED RESOURCES FOR BEACH PATROLS AND STAFFING LIFEGUARD TOWERS AT LOCATIONS AND TIMES WHEN RIP CURRENT HAZARDS ARE GREATEST.
SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

PURPOSE: CURRENT CULTURE-BASED METHODS USED BY MOST REGULATORS TO MONITOR RECREATIONAL WATERS FOR FECAL INDICATOR BACTERIA (FIB) ARE NOT SUFFICIENT TO PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH BECAUSE THERE IS A 24-HOUR LAG TIME BETWEEN SAMPLING TIME AND RESULTS. TOOLS WITH LOWER COSTS AND MORE RAPID RESPONSE TIMES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A NECESSITY TO IMPROVE POLLUTANT FORECASTING IN COASTAL MANAGEMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER THE ADVANCEMENT OF TWO IN SITU WATER QUALITY TECHNOLOGIES THAT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE CURRENT AND FUTURE IMPACTS OF TERRESTRIAL DERIVED SEWAGE AND FECAL MATTER ON COASTAL WATER QUALITY. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: MEASUREMENTS FROM A CONTINUOUS, REALTIME LOGGING FLUORESCENCE PROBE WILL BE COMPARED WITH PAIRED ENTEROCOCCUS SPP. VALUES IN THE ALA WAI CANAL, ALA WAI HARBOR AND NEARBY SURF/RECREATION ZONES. WATER SAMPLES TAKEN BEFORE, DURING, AND AFTER STORM EVENTS AND KING TIDES WILL BE EVALUATED FOR ALL THREE TYPES OF WASTEWATER INDICATOR METHODOLOGIES USED IN THIS STUDY

PURPOSE: IN THIS PROJECT, THE SC SEA GRANT CONSORTIUM (SCSGC), SC DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (SCDNR), LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY (LSU), AND THE COLLEGE OF CHARLESTON (COFC) PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A MULTI-SECTORAL FRAMEWORK TO ASSIST DECISION MAKING FOR POTENTIAL THIN-LAYER SEDIMENT PLACEMENT (TLP) SITES IN SC. "THIN-LAYER PLACEMENT," ALSO KNOW AS "THIN-LAYER SEDIMENT ADDITION" AND "MARSH NOURISHMENT," IS A PROCESS WHERE SEDIMENT REMOVED FROM NAVIGATION CHANNELS DURING DREDGING IS TRANSPORTED TO A MARSH BY PIPELINE OR BARGE AND APPLIED TO THE SURFACE OF THE MARSH BY SPRAYING A SLURRY OF WATER, SAND, AND SILT. THIS HAS BEEN PROPOSED AS A MEANS OF RESTORING MARSH ELEVATIONS BECAUSE, IN ADDITION TO MINIMIZING SPOIL BANK IMPACT, THIN-LAYER DEPOSITION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO RESTORE SOIL ELEVATIONS IN SUBSIDING COASTAL MARSHES. 
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: POTENTIAL TLP LOCATIONS WILL BE ASSESSED FROM AN ECONOMIC, REGULATORY, ECOLOGICAL, AND SOCIOCULTURAL LENS, AND THEN REPRESENTATIVE SITES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN A GEOMORPHOLOGICAL MODEL (MARSHMORPHO2D) TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL FOR SUCCESS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ENGAGE WITH A DIVERSE GROUP OF STAKEHOLDERS TO DEFINE TLP SUCCESS AND DISCUSS EXPECTED BENEFITS OF TLP. THE EVALUATION OF ECOMORPHOLOGICAL BENEFITS FROM TLP (E.G. MARSH AREA RESTORED AND AREA PREVENTED FROM BEING LOST) WILL DIRECTLY BUILD UPON A PREVIOUSLY FUNDED USCRP PROJECT, 'BRIDGING THE GAP BETWEEN PROCESS-BASED MARSH EVOLUTION MODELS AND DATA-DRIVEN METRICS OF MARSH HEALTH.'

EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THROUGH MEANINGFUL CO-PRODUCTION WITH A DIVERSE GROUP OF SPECIALTIES, THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY CONSIDERATIONS FOR TLP TO BE FEASIBLE AND SUCCESSFUL IN SC AND CREATE A TRANSFERABLE FRAMEWORK FOR FUTURE WORK WITHIN AND BEYOND THE STATE. THE TWO MAIN DELIVERABLES ARE (1) A SOUTH CAROLINA-SPECIFIC TLP DECISION SUPPORT TOOL, AND (2) A TRANSFERRABLE TLP DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORK. THE TOOL WILL BE IN THE FORM OF A WEBSITE THAT INCLUDES: A) BACKGROUND INFORMATION ON MARSHES AND TLP, INCLUDING ADDITIONAL LITERATURE AND RESOURCES; B) MAP OF ALL SITES IN SC THAT WERE CONSIDERED FOR TLP; C) RESULTS OF THE ECONOMIC, ECOLOGICAL, AND SOCIO-CULTURAL ANALYSIS DISPLAYED FOR ALL THE MARSH SITES IN SC THAT WERE CONSIDERED FOR TLP; D) RESULTS OF THE REGULATORY GAP ANALYSIS; E) RESULTS OF COPRODUCED MODELING SCENARIOS OF FUTURE MARSH EVOLUTION WITH TLP, ACCESSIBLE IN AN INTERACTIVE WAY THROUGH DROP-DOWN MENUS (E.G. MARSH TYPES, SLR RATES, TLP STRATEGIES); AND F) ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTATION DESCRIBING THE MODEL AND ITS VALIDATION FOR THE SC MARSHES. ALL THE MODEL SIMULATIONS WILL BE UPLOADED, INCLUDING THE SOURCE CODE, THE INPUT DATA, AND THE MODELED SCENARIO, ON APPROPRIATE REPOSITORIES.
INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE ANTICIPATED BENEFITS OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE (1) A MODEL-ASSISTED DECISION SUPPORT TOOL TO ASSESS WHICH SC SALT MARSHES MAY BENEFIT FROM TLP; (2) A MULTI-SECTOR COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE FOCUSING ON PROACTIVE MEASURES TO BUILD COASTAL RESILIENCE OF SC; (3) A TRANSFERRABLE FRAMEWORK FOR FUTURE TLP DECISION-MAKERS ON THE MULTIPLE CONSIDERATIONS THAT NEED TO BE WEIGHED IN ORDER TO ENSURE TLP SUCCESS.
SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: DR. MARIOTTI OF LSU WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT, CALIBRATION, AND APPLICATION OF THE MARSH EVOLUTION MODEL, SUPERVISION OF THE GRADUATE STUDENT, AND PREPARATION OF PROGRESS REPORTS AND SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS REPORTING PROJECT RESULTS. GRADUATE STUDENTS: FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $28,000 ARE REQUESTED FOR A GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIP. THE STUDENT WILL CONDUCT THE MODEL SIMULATIONS AND CREATE THE INPUTS FOR THE WEBSITE TOOL, UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF DR. MARIOTTI.

PURPOSE: OREGON'S ESTUARIES FACE EXISTING FLOOD RISK AND UNCERTAIN FUTURE CHANGES TO THAT RISK. THEREFORE, PLANNING PROCESSES IN THE STATE ARE FOCUSED ON IDENTIFYING AND PRIORITIZING A RANGE OF ADAPTATION MEASURES AIMED AT INCREASING COASTAL COMMUNITY RESILIENCE. HYBRID STATISTICAL-DYNAMICAL MODELS HAVE INCREASED OUR ABILITY TO DEVELOP ROBUST (PROBABILISTIC) COASTAL FLOOD RISK ASSESSMENTS WITH REDUCED COMPUTATIONAL DEMAND. THE PIS PROPOSE TO IMPROVE, MODIFY, AND APPLY A USCRP FUNDED HYBRID FRAMEWORK FOR ESTIMATING COMPOUND FLOOD RISK, AND TO CO-DEVELOP A SUITE OF ONLINE TOOLS AND PRODUCTS FOR DIRECT IMPLEMENTATION INTO AN ONGOING ESTUARINE PLANNING PROCESS IN OREGON.
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PIS WILL CONTINUE TO IMPROVE, MODIFY, AND APPLY A USCRP FUNDED HYBRID FRAMEWORK FOR ESTIMATING COMPOUND FLOOD RISK TO AN ONGOING ESTUARINE COASTAL COMMUNITY RESILIENCE PLANNING PROCESS, AND TO CO-DEVELOP A SUITE OF ONLINE TOOLS AND PRODUCTS TO ENHANCE DECISION-MAKING IN SEVERAL OREGON COASTAL COMMUNITIES. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE:
COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OBJECTIVE 1: INCORPORATE RESULTS FROM THE FRAMEWORK FOR COMPOUND RISK ASSESSMENT INTO OREGON'S COASTAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAM'S ESTUARINE RESILIENCE ACTION PLANNING PROCESS UNDERWAY FOR ONE OREGON ESTUARY AND PLANNED FOR TWO ADDITIONAL ESTUARIES.
COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OBJECTIVE 2: CO-PRODUCE A SUITE OF TOOLS AND GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS FOR A RANGE OF STAKEHOLDERS AND DECISION-MAKERS TO EXPLORE HOW THE REGION'S LONG-TERM RISK TO COMPOUND COASTAL FLOOD HAZARDS MIGHT BE TRANSFORMED UNDER DIFFERENT CLIMATE SCENARIOS.
EDUCATION OBJECTIVE 1: TRAIN EARLY CAREER RESEARCHERS (GRA, UG RESEARCHERS) IN CONVERGENT, TRANSDISCIPLINARY APPROACHES TO DEVELOPING ACTIONABLE COASTAL HAZARDS RESEARCH AND PRODUCTS.
EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AN ASSORTED SUITE OF PRODUCTS DEVELOPED BY THIS PROJECT WILL AIM TO INFORM AND EDUCATE DIVERSE AUDIENCES. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE PRESENTATIONS, PUBLICATIONS, AN ENHANCED COASTAL FLOODING HYBRID MODELING FRAMEWORK, A "COASTAL FLOOD TOOL" FOR ACCESSING AND VISUALIZING PROBABILISTIC FLOOD PREDICTIONS, A COASTAL FLOOD TOOL USER GUIDE, AND AN ARCGIS STORYMAP. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL ALSO MEET THE FOLLOWING PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT AND COMMUNICATION REQUIREMENTS: ANNUAL PRESENTATION OF RESEARCH FINDINGS, QUARTERLY WRITTEN UPDATES, AND A RESEARCH HIGHLIGHT FOR PROGRAM COMMUNICATIONS.
INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: OREGON'S DEPARTMENT OF LAND CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT (DLCD) IS WORKING CLOSELY WITH SELECT COASTAL COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP ESTUARINE RESILIENCE ACTION PLANS (ERAPS). ERAPS IDENTIFY NEEDS, GOALS, AND PRIORITIES FOR NATURAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS TO INCREASE RESILIENCE TO THE IMPACTS OF FLOODING, STORMS, AND CLIMATE CHANGE. OREGON'S COASTAL POPULATION IS LARGELY CENTERED NEAR ITS ESTUARIES AND EXISTING ENGAGEMENT WITH A RANGE OF PARTNERS HAS HIGHLIGHTED THAT FLOODING, SEA LEVEL RISE, AND CLIMATE CHANGE ARE AMONG THE MOST CRITICAL HAZARDS THE COMMUNITY NEEDS TO PLAN FOR. KNOWLEDGE OF PRESENT DAY AND FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF FLOOD FREQUENCY, MAGNITUDE, AND IMPACTS ARE NECESSARY IN THIS PROCESS AS COMMUNITIES BEGIN TO IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE LOCAL COMMUNITY ACTIONS FOR INCREASING RESILIENCE.
SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: CREATING HYBRID STATISTICAL MODELS, SUCH AS THE APPROACH BEING IMPROVED ON BY THOMAS WAHL (UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA) AND KATHERINE SERAFIN (UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA) WITH THE EXISTING USCRP PROJECT TITLED "WHEN FORCES COLLIDE: DEVELOPING A SCALABLE FRAMEWORK FOR COMPOUND FLOOD RISK ASSESSMENT." THE USCRP PROJECT LED BY WAHL AND SERAFIN IS CHARACTERIZING TRANSITION ZONES WHERE EXTREME WATER LEVELS CAN ARISE THROUGH THE SYNCHRONOUS OR SUCCESSIVE INTERACTION OF MULTIPLE DRIVERS SUCH AS ELEVATED RIVER DISCHARGE, STORM SURGE, AND HIGH TIDE. THEIR EFFORT IS IDENTIFYING AREAS WHERE FEMA'S NATIONAL FLOOD INSURANCE PROGRAM MAY BE MISCHARACTERIZING TRUE FLOOD RISK BY TREATING FLUVIAL AND COASTAL FLOODING DRIVERS INDEPENDENTLY.

PURPOSE: IN A PREVIOUSLY FUNDED NOAA PROJECT, THE RESEARCH TEAM ESTABLISHED A CLIMATE-INFORMED, REGIONAL FLOOD RISK ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK THAT ACCOUNTS FOR COMPOUND FLOODING RISKS FOR THE SOUTHEAST TEXAS COAST AND THAT INTEGRATES INDIRECT IMPACTS OF FLOODING IN APPRAISING THE COST-EFFECTIVENESS OF VARIOUS INFRASTRUCTURE OPTIONS IN REDUCING FLOODING RISKS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS AIMED TO CAPITALIZE, AND EXPAND, AN EARLY USCRP PROJECT AND THE AFOREMENTIONED NOAA PROJECT TO SYNERGISTICALLY IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE OF ENERGY AND SUPPORTING INFRASTRUCTURE ALONG THE SOUTHEAST TEXAS COAST TO EXTREME FLOODS IN PRESENT AND FUTURE CLIMATES.
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT WILL BE CARRIED OUT IN PARTNERSHIP WITH ENERGY PRODUCERS, WATER SUPPLIERS, REGIONAL GOVERNMENTS, FLOOD MITIGATION ORGANIZATIONS, AND STATE AGENCIES OVERSEEING FLOOD PLANNING AND COASTAL RESILIENCE. IT WILL CONSIST OF THREE MAJOR THRUSTS. THE FIRST IS ON APPLYING THE RISK ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK TO COLLABORATIVELY APPRAISE THE FUTURE FLOODING RISK EXPOSURES OF EXISTING AS WELL AS PLANNED ENERGY AND WATER INFRASTRUCTURE. THE SECOND FOCUSES ON EVALUATING CANDIDATE ADAPTATION MEASURES IDENTIFIED BY REGIONAL PARTNERS TO DETERMINE THEIR COST-EFFICACY WHILE CONSIDERING SPILLOVER ECONOMIC EFFECTS OF DISRUPTION OF ENERGY SUPPLY ON REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCALES. THE THIRD INVOLVES INTEGRATION OF THE OUTCOMES IN THE REGIONAL COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE MANAGEMENT PLANS.
EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PROJECT OUTCOMES AND DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: 1. MAPS OF FLOOD RISK EXPOSURE OF MAJOR ENERGY AND WATER INFRASTRUCTURE ALONG THE TEXAS COAST IN CURRENT AND FUTURE CLIMATES WITH DIFFERENTIATION OF SALINE/FRESHWATER FLOODING. 2. REPORTS ON INDIVIDUAL AND CUMULATIVE ECONOMIC VALUES OF DIFFERENT ADAPTATION MEASURES ON A NATIONAL LEVEL THAT ACCOUNT FOR THE INTERDEPENDENCE OF WATER ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE. 3. RECOMMENDATIONS ON INFRASTRUCTURE PLANS TO STATE AND REGIONAL GOVERNMENTS THAT WILL IMPROVE ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF UNDERSERVED, DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. 4. EDUCATION MODULE FOR THE WIDER DISSEMINATION OF THE RESULTS AND IMPROVISED THROUGH DELIVERY AT COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS IN THE REGION.
INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE STUDY REGION ENCOMPASSES URBAN CENTERS WITH LARGE, UNDERSERVED MINORITY POPULATIONS. AFRICAN AMERICANS CONSTITUTE 48.5% OF THE POPULATION OF BEAUMONT AND 38.2% OF THE POPULATION IN PORT ARTHUR. THIS REGION SUFFERED DISPROPORTIONATELY HIGH LOSSES IN PROPERTIES AND  EMPLOYMENT DURING HARVEY - BLACK (73%), HISPANIC (79%), AND LOW-INCOME (79%). THE CRITICALITY OF THE REGION'S AGING ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE, COUPLED WITH THE RELATIVELY LOWER CAPACITY OF THE COMMUNITIES IN ADEQUATELY PLANNING FOR THE RESILIENCE AND CONTINUITY REQUIRES SUPPORT FROM PROGRAMS SUCH AS USCRP. THE OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT CAN DIRECTLY BE APPLICABLE TO OTHER SIMILAR COMMUNITIES ALONG THE COAST.
SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: SENIOR PERSONNEL AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS  AT THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT ARLINGTON AND LAMAR UNIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE CONFERENCE SUPPORT AND TRAVEL TO BEAUMONT, TX TO MEET WITH STAKEHOLDERS.

PURPOSE: MOMENTUM IS BUILDING AROUND THE UTILIZATION OF NATURAL AND NATURE BASED FEATURES (NNBF) AS MULTI-BENEFICIAL, MORE RESILIENT ALTERNATIVES TO TRADITIONAL SHORELINE ARMORING. BUT GAPS REMAIN IN NNBF KNOWLEDGE AND PRACTICE, AS REFLECTED BY US COASTAL RESEARCH PROGRAM PRIORITIES. BUILDING OFF PRE-EXISTING WORK AND INTEGRATING USCRP RESEARCH, THE PIS PROPOSE TO COPRODUCE FORUMS, WORKSHOPS, DATA VISUALIZATION, AND COMMUNICATIONS PRODUCTS THAT CONNECT DIVERSE END-USERS WITH RELEVANT EXPERTISE ABOUT NNBF. THROUGH THE PROCESS, THEY WILL FORMALIZE A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE, BUILD LEADERSHIP CAPACITY IN A CUNY GRADUATE STUDENT, AND SHARE KEY FINDINGS WITH LOCAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL AUDIENCES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: IT IS CRITICAL THAT ONGOING EFFORTS, DATA, EXPERIENCES, AND RELATED RESEARCH FINDINGS ARE TRANSLATED INTO FORMATS SUITABLE FOR USE BY DECISION-MAKERS, PRACTITIONERS, AND OTHER CRITICAL END-USERS, AND ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THESE AUDIENCES. PURPOSE: THE PROPOSED PROJECT ASSESSES COMPOUND FLOOD RISK FOR DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES IN MILWAUKEE, WI, AND THE MUNICIPALITIES OF BENTON HARBOR AND ST. JOSEPH IN BERRIEN COUNTY, MI, ALONG WITH PARTICIPATION OF THOSE COMMUNITIES TO CO-CREATE CRITICALLY NEEDED TOOLS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PROPOSED FLOOD RISK MITIGATION MEASURES. THIS WORK BUILDS OFF PREVIOUS U.S. COASTAL RESEARCH PROGRAM (USCRP)-FUNDED PROJECTS THAT EMPHASIZED THE NECESSITY OF COMPOUND FLOOD RISK ASSESSMENT FOR MARINE COASTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT BEGINS WITH THE DYNAMICAL DOWNSCALING OF GLOBAL CLIMATE MODEL (GCM) SIMULATIONS FOR THE LATE 20TH, MID-21ST, AND LATE 21ST CENTURIES OVER THE GREAT LAKES REGION USING A STATE-OF-THE-ART HIGH RESOLUTION COUPLED REGIONAL CLIMATE MODEL-3D LAKE MODEL. NEXT, THE DOWNSCALED STATIC LAKE LEVEL, AIR PRESSURE, WIND VECTOR, AND PRECIPITATION DATA WILL BE USED TO DRIVE A COUPLED HYDRODYNAMIC AND WAVE MODEL BASED ON THE GREAT LAKES COASTAL FORECASTING SYSTEM

PURPOSE: THE KNAUSS FELLOWSHIP PROVIDES A ONE-YEAR EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN AN EXECUTIVE OR LEGISLATIVE BRANCH OFFICE WHICH WILL: 1) EXPAND THE STUDENT'S EXPERIENCE WITH, AND KNOWLEDGE OF, THE POLICY-MAKING PROCESS WITHIN FEDERAL AGENCIES AND CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEALING WITH MARINE AND COASTAL ISSUES; AND 2) ALLOW THE STUDENT TO CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE GAINED IN ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE INFORMATIONAL FEEDBACK TO PROGRAMS, THUS ASSISTING IN THE STUDENT'S LONG-TERM CAREER AND EDUCATIONAL GOALS. PURPOSE: THE KNAUSS FELLOWSHIP PROVIDES A ONE-YEAR EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN AN EXECUTIVE OR LEGISLATIVE BRANCH OFFICE WHICH WILL: 1) EXPAND THE STUDENT'S EXPERIENCE WITH, AND KNOWLEDGE OF, THE POLICY-MAKING PROCESS WITHIN FEDERAL AGENCIES AND CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEALING WITH MARINE AND COASTAL ISSUES; AND 2) ALLOW THE STUDENT TO CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE GAINED IN ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE INFORMATIONAL FEEDBACK TO PROGRAMS, THUS ASSISTING IN THE STUDENT'S LONG-TERM CAREER AND EDUCATIONAL GOALS.
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PROVIDE PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON POLICY-MAKING TRAINING ON MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES TO THE GRADUATE STUDENT WITH HOSTS IN THE LEGISLATIVE AND EXECUTIVE BRANCHES OF GOVERNMENT IN THE WASHINGTON, D.C. AREA.
DELIVERABLES: EACH FELLOW WILL BE EXPECTED TO PROVIDE A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND A SIX MONTH AND YEAR END PERFORMANCE REVIEW.
EXPECTED OUTCOME: THE YEAR SPENT AS A KNAUSS FELLOW AUGMENTS THE STUDENT'S EDUCATION BY PROVIDING PRACTICAL TRAINING AND UNDERSTANDING OF HOW MARINE ISSUES ARE HANDLED AT THE FEDERAL LEVEL.  THIS FELLOWSHIP WILL BENEFIT THE STUDENT, AS WELL AS CONTRIBUTE TO THE POOL OF YOUNG AND EXPERIENCED GRADUATES WITH KNOWLEDGE AND DESIRE TO PURSUE CAREERS IN MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESEARCH, POLICY, AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.

ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PROVIDE PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON POLICY-MAKING TRAINING ON MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES TO THE GRADUATE STUDENT WITH HOSTS IN THE LEGISLATIVE AND EXECUTIVE BRANCHES OF GOVERNMENT IN THE WASHINGTON, D.C. AREA.
DELIVERABLES: EACH FELLOW WILL BE EXPECTED TO PROVIDE A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND A SIX MONTH AND YEAR END PERFORMANCE REVIEW.
EXPECTED OUTCOME: THE YEAR SPENT AS A KNAUSS FELLOW AUGMENTS THE STUDENT'S EDUCATION BY PROVIDING PRACTICAL TRAINING AND UNDERSTANDING OF HOW MARINE ISSUES ARE HANDLED AT THE FEDERAL LEVEL.  THIS FELLOWSHIP WILL BENEFIT THE STUDENT, AS WELL AS CONTRIBUTE TO THE POOL OF YOUNG AND EXPERIENCED GRADUATES WITH KNOWLEDGE AND DESIRE TO PURSUE CAREERS IN MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESEARCH, POLICY, AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.

THIS FELLOWSHIP WILL BENEFIT THE STUDENT, AS WELL AS CONTRIBUTE TO THE POOL OF YOUNG AND EXPERIENCED GRADUATES WITH KNOWLEDGE AND DESIRE TO PURSUE CAREERS IN MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESEARCH, POLICY, AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.

PURPOSE: THE KNAUSS FELLOWSHIP PROVIDES A ONE-YEAR EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN AN EXECUTIVE OR LEGISLATIVE BRANCH OFFICE WHICH WILL: 1) EXPAND THE STUDENT'S EXPERIENCE WITH, AND KNOWLEDGE OF, THE POLICY-MAKING PROCESS WITHIN FEDERAL AGENCIES AND CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEALING WITH MARINE AND COASTAL ISSUES; AND 2) ALLOW THE STUDENT TO CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE GAINED IN ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE INFORMATIONAL FEEDBACK TO PROGRAMS, THUS ASSISTING IN THE STUDENT'S LONG-TERM CAREER AND EDUCATIONAL GOALS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PROVIDE PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON POLICY-MAKING TRAINING ON MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES TO THE GRADUATE STUDENT WITH HOSTS IN THE LEGISLATIVE AND EXECUTIVE BRANCHES OF GOVERNMENT IN THE WASHINGTON, D.C. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD ALLOW THE APPLICANT TO OPERATE A SINGLE PILOT-SCALE MARINE AQUACULTURE FACILITY WITH UP TO 20,000 ALMACO JACK (SERIOLA RIVOLIANA) BEING REARED IN FEDERAL WATERS FOR A PERIOD OF APPROXIMATELY 12 MONTHS. BASED ON AN ESTIMATED 85 PERCENT SURVIVAL RATE, THE OPERATION IS EXPECTED TO YIELD APPROXIMATELY 17,000 FISH. FINAL FISH SIZE IS ESTIMATED TO BE APPROXIMATELY 4.4 LBS/FISH, RESULTING IN AN ESTIMATED FINAL MAXIMUM HARVEST WEIGHT OF 88,000 LBS (OR 74,800 LBS CONSIDERING THE SURVIVAL RATE). THE FINGERLINGS WILL BE SOURCED FROM BROOD STOCK THAT ARE LOCATED AT MOTE AQUACULTURE RESEARCH PARK AND WERE CAUGHT IN THE GULF NEAR MADEIRA BEACH, FLORIDA. AS SUCH, ONLY FILIAL 1 (F1) PROGENY WILL BE STOCKED INTO THE OFFSHORE NET PEN. FOLLOWING HARVEST, CULTURED FISH WOULD BE LANDED IN FLORIDA AND SOLD TO FEDERALLY-LICENSED DEALERS IN ACCORDANCE WITH STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL BE MAKING ALL OF THE MONITORING DATA, PRODUCTION DATA, AND ECONOMIC DATA GENERATED

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS ACTIVITY IS TO INVESTIGATE THE DRIVERS OF AQUATIC CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN (CEC) IN THE SOUTHEASTERN COASTAL STATES (SPECIFICALLY SOUTH CAROLINA, GEORGIA, FLORIDA) AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL MITIGATION SOLUTIONS.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENTS WILL FIRST WORK WITH GRADUATE AND LAW STUDENTS TO CONDUCT LITERATURE AND POLICY REVIEWS AND A LEGAL SCAN TO IDENTIFY HOW CECS ARE ADDRESSED IN THE SOUTHEAST. THE LITERATURE REVIEW WILL FORM THE BASIS OF A GAP AND NETWORK ANALYSIS TO HELP ASSEMBLE AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE (AC) OF COMMUNITY LEADERS AND EXPORTS. THE AC WILL ENGAGE IN THE PROCESS OF IDENTIFYING COMMUNITY NEEDS AND REFINING RESEARCH QUESTIONS TO ADDRESS THROUGH A COMPETITIVE RESEARCH PROGRAM. A STUDY GROUP MODEL, BLENDING FACULTY MEMBERS AND STUDENTS WITH STATE AGENCY REPRESENTATIVES, COMMUNITY LEADERS AND EXTENSION SPECIALISTS, WILL BE USED TO CARRY OUT RESEARCH AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES BASED ON PRIORITY NEEDS. RESEARCH MAY FOCUS ON TOPICS

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT SOCIO-ECONOMIC RESEARCH ON THE IMPACT OF POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN GREAT LAKES STATES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE RISK, EXPOSURE, AND REMEDIATION OF THESE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENTS WILL FIRST PARTNER WITH STATE AND TRIBAL AGENCIES TO DIRECTLY INFORM DEVELOPMENT OF A GREAT LAKES REGION RESEARCH COMPETITION REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.  ANTICIPATED RESEARCH SCOPES COULD, FOR EXAMPLE, IDENTIFY HOW TO EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATE RISK OF PFAS EXPOSURE IN VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES, IDENTIFY BEHAVIORS THAT LIMIT RISK OF PFAS EXPOSURE OR NEGATIVE IMPACTS, OR QUANTIFY ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF SUGGESTED PFAS REMEDIATION PRACTICES. SUCCESSFUL PROPOSALS WILL THEN BE REQUIRED TO PARTNER WITH AT LEAST ONE GREAT LAKES REGION SEA GRANT PARTNER TO SUPPORT OUTREACH ACTIVITIES AND WILL BE EXPECTED TO ENGAGE WITH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND/OR STATE OR TRIBAL AGENCIES. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE BAD RIVER TRIBE AS PART OF NMFS' TRIBAL COMMERCIAL FISHING COVID-19 RELIEF. THE SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDES DIRECT PAYMENTS TO TRIBAL FISHERMEN, PROGRAMMING FOR YOUTH AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND EQUIPMENT FOR TRIBAL FISHERMEN. THIS PROJECT IS BEING FUNDED BY NOAA WITH FY2022 FUNDS AFTER THE INITIAL APPLICATION WAS INADVERTENTLY OVERLOOKED DURING THE FY2021 RELIEF OPPORTUNITY.

THIS INSTITUTIONAL ACTION PROVIDES $62,995 TO NEW HAMPSHIRE SEA GRANT FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY VIA AN INTERAGENCY AGREEMENT. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ESTABLISH A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN NEW HAMPSHIRE PUBLIC BROADCASTING (NHPBS) AND NEW HAMPSHIRE SEA GRANT TO CREATE A VARIETY OF INFORMATIONAL STORIES THAT EXPLAIN MANY ASPECTS OF HARNESSING OFFSHORE WIND IN THE GULF OF MAINE. THROUGH INTERVIEWS WITH SCIENTISTS, RESEARCHERS, BIOLOGISTS, PEOPLE WHO MAKE THEIR LIVING ON THE WATER, AND OTHERS, NEW HAMPSHIRE SEA GRANT AND THE NHPBS WILL FURTHER ENGAGEMENT AND EDUCATION IN THE STATE REGARDING OFFSHORE WIND IN THE GULF OF MAINE.

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS THE TESTING AND EVALUATION OF VARIOUS GEAR MODIFICATION TECHNOLOGIES ABOARD COMMERCIAL VESSELS, INCLUDING SPRING-TAG AND TIMED RELEASE SYSTEMS AND SUBSEA GEAR LOCATION INTEGRATIONS WITH CHART PLOTTING SYSTEMS, AND WILL COLLECT INFORMATION ON THE PERFORMANCE OF THESE SYSTEMS AND HOW TIME SPENT FISHING AND TRAP RETRIEVAL SUCCESS ARE AFFECTED. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS PROJECT WILL OUTFIT SELECT AND VOLUNTARY LOBSTER INDUSTRY PARTICIPANTS ACROSS MULTIPLE FISHING AREAS WITH EITHER THE TAGLINE SPRING RELEASE OR TIMED RELEASE SYSTEM DESIGNED BY NOVA ROBOTICS. THESE SYSTEMS BOTH UTILIZE RELATIVELY LOW-COST AND ACCESSIBLE TECHNOLOGIES TO ALLOW FISHERMEN TO ACCESS A STOWED ROPE OF TRADITIONAL STRENGTH AND SAFETY, WHILE PROVIDING A REDUCTION IN THE RISK OF ENTANGLEMENT TO RIGHT WHALES BY EITHER REDUCING THE STRENGTH OF THE LINE OR THE AMOUNT OF TIME IT OCCURS IN THE WATER COLUMN. PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE TOOLS FOR ECOSYSTEM BASED FISHERIES MANAGEMENT, WITH A FOCUS ON INCORPORATING CLIMATE CHANGE-DRIVEN FLUCTUATIONS IN SPECIES ABUNDANCE AND PRODUCTIVITY.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT INVOLVES FOOD WEB MODELING IN RPATH (AN OPEN-SOURCE PACKAGE DEVELOPED BY NOAA), AND THE MANIPULATION AND ANALYSIS OF THESE FOOD WEB MODELS. SPECIFICALLY, BY INTEGRATING TWO EXTANT OPEN-SOURCE R PACKAGES TO FACILITATE COMPUTATION OF ECOSYSTEM INDICATORS AND REFERENCE POINTS ENABLING MODELING OF HOW AN ECOSYSTEM'S RESILIENCE AND EFFICIENCY ARE IMPACTED BY VARIATION IN SPECIES-LEVEL PARAMETER VALUES. PURPOSE: THE PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE EFFECTS ON LOCAL LABOR MARKETS THROUGH EMPLOYMENT, EARNINGS, AND GOVERNMENT TRANSFER PAYMENTS FROM THE INTRODUCTION OF AN INDIVIDUAL TRADABLE QUOTA SYSTEM AND COMPARE TO THE INCREASES IN EFFICIENCY OF THE FISHERIES DUE TO THE TRADABILITY OF FISHING RIGHTS. IT WILL USE THE STAGGERED INTRODUCTION OF THE INDIVIDUAL TRADABLE QUOTA SYSTEMS IN ICELAND AMONG LARGE VESSELS (IN 1991) AND SMALL ONES (IN 2001).  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT WILL ESTIMATE THE EFFECT ON EMPLOYMENT AND EARNINGS OF CREWS ON FISHING BOATS ENTERING THE TRADABLE QUOTA SYSTEM, USING A DIFFERENCE-IN-DIFFERENCE DESIGN COMPARING EARNINGS AND EMPLOYMENT OF WORKERS IN VESSELS PLACED IN THE INDIVIDUAL TRADABLE QUOTA SYSTEMS TO WORKERS OUTSIDE THE FISHERY. THE HETEROGENEITY IN THESE EFFECTS BY GEOGRAPHY, AGE OF WORKERS, WHETHER THE CREW-MEMBERS' FIRMS EXIT OR NOT, AND LOCAL ECONOMIC CONDITIONS WILL THEN BE ASSESSED. PURPOSE: THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO DEVELOP A NOVEL STOCK ASSESSMENT MODEL TO EXPLICITLY ACCOUNT FOR SEASONALLY VARYING NATURAL MORTALITY RATES IN THE SPOTTED SEATROUT STOCK IN NORTH CAROLINA AND VIRGINIA.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED SEASONAL SIZE-STRUCTURED MODEL WITH TAGGING SUB-MODEL FOR THE NORTH CAROLINA AND VIRGINIA STOCK OF SPOTTED SEATROUT TO BETTER ACCOUNT FOR THE EFFECTS OF COLD STUN EVENTS ON THE POPULATION DYNAMICS. THE PROJECT INVOLVES CONDUCTING SIMULATION-ESTIMATION EXPERIMENTS TO EVALUATE THE RELIABILITY OF MODEL ESTIMATES ASSUMING THE MODEL IS CORRECT (I.E., SELF-TEST), TO EVALUATE THE ABILITY TO ESTIMATE NATURAL MORTALITY DUE TO COLD STUNS, AND TO QUANTIFY THE PERFORMANCE OF DIFFERENT WAYS TO INCORPORATE PROCESS ERRORS.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES: METHODS AND A FRAMEWORK FOR SPOTTED SEATROUT THAT IS ABLE TO UTILIZE TAGGING DATA THROUGH INTEGRATING A TAGGING SUB-MODEL AND ESTIMATE TIME-VARYING NATURAL MORTALITY RATES. PURPOSE:  THE PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE METHODS FOR IMPROVING STABILITY IN U.S. COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND EVALUATING THE FREQUENCY OF STOCK ASSESSMENTS TO ENSURE MONITORING RESOURCES ARE INVESTED EFFICIENTLY.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: SPECIFICALLY, MANAGEMENT STRATEGY EVALUATION WILL BE USED TO INVESTIGATE TO WHAT EXTENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES CAN MINIMIZE INTERANNUAL VARIATION IN CATCH WHEN NEW STOCK ASSESSMENTS RESULT IN A LARGE INCREASE OR DECREASE IN CATCH RECOMMENDATIONS. A SIMULATION APPROACH WILL EXPLORE THE BEHAVIOR OF A RECENTLY IMPLEMENTED METHOD FOR DETERMINING BUFFERS FOR CATCH LIMITS FOR STOCKS WITH AGING STOCK ASSESSMENTS ADOPTED BY THE PACIFIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DATA AND INFORMATION OBTAINED THROUGH THIS  RESEARCH WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS ADVANCING STOCK ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGY FOR PRODUCING SCIENTIFIC ADVICE FOR THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LIVING MARINE RESOURCES. PURPOSE: IN 2018, THE TWO PRIMARY CHINOOK SALMON STOCKS TARGETED BY FISHERIES IN CALIFORNIA, SACRAMENTO RIVER FALL CHINOOK AND KLAMATH RIVER FALL CHINOOK, WERE DESIGNATED AS OVERFISHED AFTER CONSECUTIVE LOW RETURNS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO EVALUATE IF OCEAN DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS FOR THESE AND OTHER STOCKS OF CONCERN HAVE CHANGED, AND TO ASSESS THE VALUE OF INCORPORATING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION INTO SACRAMENTO RIVER FALL CHINOOK ABUNDANCE FORECASTS.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROPOSAL INCLUDES DEVELOPING A HIERARCHICAL MODEL THAT WILL INTEGRATE COHORT DATA ACROSS STOCKS, EVALUATING THE PERFORMANCE OF TWO ALTERNATIVE SACRAMENTO RIVER FALL CHINOOK FORECAST MODELS, AND CONDUCTING A VALUE OF INFORMATION ANALYSIS ON COLLECTING AGE STRUCTURE DATA FOR FORECASTING.  THE PROJECT AIMS TO RECONSTRUCT PAST COHORTS BY COMBINING INFORMATION FROM MULTIPLE CALIFORNIA SALMON STOCKS TO ENABLE ESTIMATION OF NATURAL MORTALITY AND MATURATION, IN ORDER TO DETERMINE WHETHER VITAL RATES OF SACRAMENTO

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO BUILD UPON NYSG'S PREVIOUS WORK FUNDED THROUGH THE AQUACULTURE SUPPLEMENTAL TO USE THOSE RELATIONSHIPS TO CONNECT INDUSTRY TOGETHER, AND DEVELOP A UNIFIED NETWORK OF PRODUCERS AND STAKEHOLDERS. THE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THE WORK ARE TO: 1) ESTABLISH AN ANNUAL SURVEY OF THE INDUSTRY TO PUBLISH ANNUAL REPORTS; 2) ESTABLISH ANNUAL MEETINGS OF THE INDUSTRY IN BOTH UPSTATE NY AND LONG ISLAND; AND 3) COORDINATE A TASK FORCE TO DEVELOP RESOURCES TO HELP NAVIGATE THE REGULATORY LANDSCAPE. PROPOSED WORK TO ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES INCLUDES: 1) CREATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF AN ANNUAL SURVEY FOR AQUACULTURE PRODUCERS IN THE STATE; 2) ESTABLISHING ANNUAL MEETINGS OF AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS; 3) COORDINATION OF A TASK FORCE, OR SEVERAL, INCLUDING AGENCIES AND INDUSTRY TO EXPLORE THE PROCESS FOR PERMITTING DIFFERENT TYPES OF AQUACULTURE IN DIFFERENT REGIONS; 4) PROVIDING FUNDING AND SUPPORT FOR AN AQUACULTURE SPEAKER AND AQUACULTURE PRODUCTS AT NEW YORK SEA GRANT'S ANNUA

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ENABLE KELP FARMING TO BE COMMERCIALLY COMPETITIVE WITH DOMESTIC LAND-BASED FARM PRODUCTION AND OCEAN-BASED PRODUCTION ABROAD, AND TO FULFILL STRICT REGULATIONS THAT PROTECT THE HEALTH AND GENETIC DIVERSITY OF NATIVE KELP POPULATIONS IN PARTICULAR. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) DEVELOPMENT OF A BREEDING STRATEGY TO MAKE BEST USE OF GAMETOPHYTE EX SITU SEED BANKS DEVELOPED BY ESTABLISHED BREEDING PROGRAMS FOR GROWING SPORELESS KELP, 2) VERIFICATION OF THE COMPLETE INABILITY OF KELP SPOROPHYTES TO REPRODUCE DUE TO NATURAL MUTATIONS THAT PREVENT MEIOSIS REQUIRED FOR SPORE PRODUCTION, AND 3) UTILIZE RESEARCH FACILITIES AND COMMERCIAL SEAWEED FARMING OPERATIONS TO EVALUATE AND DEMONSTRATE SPORELESS TECHNOLOGY. THIS PROJECT ENTAILS LABORATORY-BASED EXPERIMENTS AND FIELD-BASED WORK, THE LATTER WHICH WILL CONSIST OF EVALUATING SPORELESS KELP GROWTH AT A COMMERCIAL SEAWEED FARM. OUTCOMES OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ENABLE THE PRODUCTION OF SPORELESS KELP, WHICH WILL INCRE

LUMPFISH (CYCLOPTERUS LUMPUS) ARE USED IN NORWAY, SCOTLAND, AND EASTERN CANADA AS CLEANER FISH FOR BIOLOGICAL CONTROL OF PARASITIC SEA LICE ON FARMED SALMONIDS, PRIMARILY ATLANTIC SALMON. SEA LICE IMPOSE CONSIDERABLE BIOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, AND SOCIAL TOLLS ON SALMON AQUACULTURE.  THE PROJECT SEEKS TO ESTABLISH A GEOGRAPHICALLY DIVERSE, SELF-SUSTAINING US-SOURCED BREEDING COLONY OF LUMPFISH FROM WILD CAUGHT JUVENILES BY REFINING LUMPFISH BROODSTOCK CAPTURE AND HUSBANDRY PROTOCOLS; CONDITIONING FISH FOR OUT-OF-SEASON SPAWNING; ESTABLISHING AND REFINING LUMPFISH HATCHERY PRODUCTION AND PROTOCOLS; AND SCREENING FISH FOR PATHOGENS AND MICROBES. THIS PROJECT ENTAILS LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS USING RECIRCULATING AQUACULTURE SYSTEMS AND FIELD-BASED WORK, THE LATTER WHICH WILL CONSIST OF COLLECTION OF LUMPFISH FROM THE WILD TO BE RAISED AS BROODSTOCK FOR EXPERIMENTS. BY THE END OF THE PROJECT, THE RESEARCHERS WILL HAVE ESTABLISHED A DIVERSE BROODSTOCK POPULATION SOURCED FROM WILD FISH CAPTURED FROM

SPECIFICALLY THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE BASE OF EARLY-STAGE PROPAGATION AND REARING OF NOVEL MARINE FINFISH AQUACULTURE SPECIES BY OPPORTUNISTICALLY COLLECTING EGGS FROM ANIMALS SPAWNING WITHIN THE PUBLIC AQUARIUM NETWORK. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ENGAGE FIVE AQUARIUMS (NEW ENGLAND AQUARIUM, NATIONAL AQUARIUM, SHEDD AQUARIUM, AQUARIUM OF THE PACIFIC, AND THE THREE NORTH CAROLINA AQUARIUMS) IN A CONSORTED EFFORT TO REAR LARVAE AND JUVENILES OF SELECTED MARINE FINFISH SPECIES THAT ARE BREEDING ON EXHIBIT FOR EVENTUAL RETURN BACK TO EXHIBIT TO ELIMINATE THE NEED FOR WILD CAPTURE OF FISH.  ALL SITES ARE OPERATIONAL PUBLIC AQUARIUMS AND ALL RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED USING RECIRCULATING AQUACULTURE SYSTEMS PRESENT AT EACH SITE.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CREATE AND EVALUATE A NOVEL MODULAR HATCHERY APPARATUS THAT WILL CONSISTENTLY PRODUCE CONCENTRATED SEEDSTOCK SUSPENSIONS FOR MASS PRODUCTION OF KELP AND SEA LETTUCE IN LAND-BASED SEAWEED PRODUCTION SYSTEMS.  RESEARCH TO ASSESS THE HATCHERY APPARATUS WILL OCCUR AT PERMITTED ACADEMIC AND COMMERCIAL LAND-BASED SEAWEED PRODUCTION FACILITIES. ACTIVITIES WILL INVOLVE NATIVE SEAWEED SPECIES AND NO WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED OUTSIDE OF THE LAND-BASED, CONTROLLED AQUACULTURE FACILITIES. OUTCOMES FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL ENHANCE THE PRODUCTION AND AVAILABILITY OF SEAWEED SEEDSTOCK.  THIS WILL BENEFIT SEAWEED AQUACULTURE PRODUCERS EXPAND THEIR OPERATIONS AND INDUSTRY.

SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH RELIABLE BEST PRACTICES FOR LARVAL REARING AND SETTLEMENT PROTOCOLS FOR SEA SCALLOPS, IDENTIFY SEA SCALLOP HATCHERY MICROBIOMES AS THEY RELATE TO HEALTH STATUS, EXAMINE THE LARVAL IMMUNOCOMPETENCE  OF SEA SCALLOPS AND ITS RELEVANCE TO LARVAL SURVIVAL, ESTABLISH RELIABLE BEST PRACTICES FOR SEA SCALLOP BROODSTOCK CONDITIONING AND SPAWNING, EVALUATE THE ECONOMICS OF COMMERCIAL SCALE HATCHERY PRODUCTION, AND ENGAGE WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO CREATE A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE. FOR THE LARVAL-FOCUSED OBJECTIVES, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COLLECT 100 ADULT SCALLOPS FROM COBSCOOK BAY, ME TO SPAWN IN A HATCHERY SETTING, PROVIDING LARVAE FOR THE PROPOSED EXPERIMENTS. THE NUMBER OF SCALLOPS COLLECTED IS EXTREMELY SMALL RELATIVE TO THE SIZE OF THE WILD POPULATION, AND WILL BE COLLECTED UNDER A SPECIAL LICENSE ISSUED BY THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. NO ANIMALS INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT WILL BE RELEASED INTO THE WILD.

SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL USE A SERIES OF EXPERIMENTS CONDUCTED IN A LABORATORY SETTING TO REFINE THE CULTURE METHODS AND PARAMETERS FOR CLOWNFISH. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL OPTIMIZE PROTOCOLS FOR EGG HANDLING, LARVAL REARING AND JUVENILE GROWOUT; REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THE USE OF LIVE FEEDS; AND IDENTIFY THE FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THE DEVELOPMENT OF LARVAL DEFORMITIES IN CLOWNFISH. FOLLOWING THE LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS THE TEAM WILL CONDUCT AN ECONOMIC ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF THESE REFINED PROTOCOLS ON CLOWNFISH CULTURE PROFIT POTENTIAL; CONDUCT RESEARCH ON PERCEPTIONS AND PURCHASING BEHAVIOR OF ORNAMENTAL FISH WHOLESALERS, AND DISSEMINATE ALL OF THEIR RESULTS TO A VARIETY OF STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH WORKSHOPS, WEBINARS AND PUBLICATIONS.

SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO TO OPTIMIZE PROBIOTIC APPLICATION AND DELIVERY PROTOCOLS TO PROTECT PACIFIC AND EASTERN OYSTERS AS EARLY AS POSSIBLE IN LARVAL DEVELOPMENT AND TO DEVELOP METHODOLOGIES TO APPLY THE PROBIOTICS IN CO-CULTURE WITH MICROALGAL FEEDS.  PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR UNDER LABORATORY CONDITIONS, INCLUDING FLOW-THROUGH TANK TRIALS CONDUCTED AT THREE LAND-BASED COMMERCIAL SHELLFISH HATCHERIES IN OREGON, HAWAII, AND MARYLAND.  EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED ACCORDING TO ESTABLISHED LABORATORY PROTOCOLS AND PROCEDURES.  NO PROPOSED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES MAY OCCUR UNTIL REQUIRED STATE SHELLFISH TRANSPORT PERMITS AND OPERATIONAL PERMITS OF COMMERCIAL FACILITIES ARE REVIEWED BY NOAA.  AS SUCH, A SPECIFIC AWARD CONDITION (SAC) WILL BE ADDED TO THIS AWARD.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP THE CAPACITY AND KNOWLEDGE TO PRODUCE AND REFINE MICROPARTICULATE FINFISH LARVAL FEEDS AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF DIETS ON THE PERFORMANCE (GROWTH AND SURVIVAL) OF LARVAL CALIFORNIA YELLOWTAIL (SERIOLA DORSALIS) AND YELLOWTAIL AMBERJACK (S. LALANDI).  DIET DEVELOPMENT WILL OCCUR UNDER LABORATORY CONDITIONS AND FEEDING TRIALS WILL BE CONDUCTED AT PERMITTED LAND-BASED RECIRCULATING FACILITIES. OUTCOMES OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL HELP INCREASE LARVAL PERFORMANCE AND JUVENILE PRODUCTION OF SERIOLIDS, WHICH IN TURN WILL AID IN DEVELOPMENT AND EXPANSION OF AQUACULTURE OF SERIOLIDS.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE THE PRODUCTION EFFICIENCY OF CALIFORNIA YELLOWTAIL (SERIOLA DORSALIS) BY DEVELOPING TECHNIQUES FOR YEAR-ROUND PRODUCTION OF HIGH QUALITY EGGS AND INCREASING THE CONSISTENCY IN FISH QUALITY AMONG SURVIVING FINGERLINGS. ALL PROPOSED ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR UNDER LABORATORY CONDITIONS AT THE LAND-BASED AQUACULTURE RESEARCH FACILITY AT HUBBS-SEAWORLD RESEARCH INSTITUTE (HSWRI), WHICH CONSISTS OF FLOW-THROUGH AND RECIRCULATING TANK SYSTEMS.  OUTCOMES OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ENHANCE THE REPRODUCTION EFFICIENCY OF CA YELLOWTAIL AND AVAILABILITY OF JUVENILES FOR GROW OUT OPERATIONS.  THIS IN TURN WILL AID IN THE EXPANSION OF THIS SEGMENT OF THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ESTABLISH A CONSISTENT JUVENILE DISTRIBUTION NETWORK FOR STRIPED BASS AQUACULTURE THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO INDUSTRY EXPANSION THROUGH EFFECTIVE DISTRIBUTION OF SEEDSTOCK.  PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED USING PERMITTED RECIRCULATING SYSTEM-BASED RESEARCH FACILITIES PRESENT AT NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY AND OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY AND WILL INVOLVE EVALUATION OF VARIOUS LARVAL AND JUVENILE REARING STRATEGIES FOR STRIPED BASS, IMPROVING SPAWNING OF CAPTIVE STRIPED BASS BROODSTOCK, AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF LARVAL AND JUVENILE PRODUCTION. OUTCOMES OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ENHANCE STRIPED BASS BROODSTOCK PERFORMANCE AND AVAILABILITY OF JUVENILE STRIPED BASS FOR GROW OUT OPERATIONS.  THIS IN TURN WILL AID IN DEVELOPMENT AND EXPANSION OF THE STRIPED BASS AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY.

THE ALASKA NATIVE TRIBAL HEALTH CONSORTIUM (ANTHC) HAS WORKED WITH THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION'S (NOAA) ALASKA REGIONAL COLLABORATION TEAM (ARCT) OVER THE LAST SIX MONTHS TO DEVELOP A PILOT PROJECT IN RESPONSE TO NOAA'S DESIRE TO ADDRESS CLIMATE AND EQUITY ISSUES ACROSS THE NATION. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND ONE FULL-TIME DIRECTOR TO LEAD CLIMATE WORK AT ANTHC. KEY ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: LEAD A LANDSCAPE ASSESSMENT OF ALL CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION ACTIVITIES IN ALASKA; ENSURE THAT ALL TRIBAL RELATED CLIMATE CHANGE EFFORTS ARE LED AND PRIORITIZED BY ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLE THROUGH THE CREATION OF AN ALASKA TRIBAL CLIMATE CHANGE ADVISORY GROUP; AND LEAD THE TRIBAL REVIEW AND PUBLICATION OF THE UNMET NEEDS OF ENVIRONMENTALLY THREATENED ALASKA NATIVE VILLAGES REPORT. THE PROPOSED PROJECT LINKS DIRECTLY TO THE FOLLOWING NOAA LONG-TERM MISSION GOAL: CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION.

PURPOSE: THE TWO-YEAR POSITION IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE PACIFIC RISCC MANAGEMENT NETWORK IN THE FORM OF AN INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE PROGRAM SPECIALIST. IT IS ANTICIPATED THIS INDIVIDUAL WILL INTERFACE CLOSELY WITH LOCAL FEDERAL STAFF AND PARTNERS, SUPPORTING A MORE HOLISTIC CONTEXT TO THE PACIFIC RISCC DEVELOPMENT. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: SERVE AS A COORDINATOR FOR THE PROGRAM, PLANNING WORKSHOPS, WRITING PLANNING DOCUMENTS, AND MAINTAINING REGULAR CONTACT WITH PARTNERS. DEVELOP AND SHARE RESOURCES FOR PARTNERS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: TO ENABLE KEY PARTNERS AND EXPERTS TO DECREASE THE THREAT TO ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND COMMUNITIES POSED BY THE INTERACTION OF CLIMATE CHANGE WITH INVASIVE, NON-NATIVE SPECIES WITHIN THE PACIFIC REGION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ALL MEMBERS OF THE PACIFIC REGION ECOSYSTEM WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS WORK, INCLUDING INDIGENOUS PLAN AND ANIMAL SPECIES.

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A PRE-DISASTER RECOVERY PLAN FOR KAUA'I COUNTY USING A COMBINATION OF DESKTOP RESEARCH, AND MEETINGS OF THE COUNTY RECOVERY WORKING GROUP AND STAKEHOLDER RECOVERY ADVISORY GROUP, AS WELL AS SCENARIO PLANNING WITH A SELECT COMMUNITY/IES.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ACTIVITIES IN THE FIRST YEAR WILL INVOLVE PROVIDING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES TO GOVERNMENT, NON-GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS ON DISASTER RECOVERY PLANNING AND DEVELOPING A CLEAR ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE AND AUTHORITY TO GOVERN RECOVERY POST DISASTER EFFORTS. THE SECOND YEAR WILL FOCUS ON WORKING WITH A SELECT COMMUNITY/IES IDENTIFIED  AS ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE AND IN NEED OF DISASTER RECOVERY PLANNING. PURPOSE: INCREASING VOLATILITY OF WATER LEVELS ON THE GREAT LAKES AND THE INCREASING FREQUENCY AND SEVERITY OF RAIN AND STORM EVENTS ACROSS WISCONSIN WILL RESULT IN DANGEROUS AND DAMAGING IMPACTS ON GREAT LAKES COASTAL COMMUNITIES. GREAT LAKES COASTAL MUNICIPALITIES HAVE LIMITED RESOURCES TO PARTICIPATE IN NATURAL DISASTER PREPAREDNESS PLANNING. THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE DISASTER-PRONE COMMUNITIES ON THE GREAT LAKES COAST IN PREPAREDNESS PLANNING.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: 1) VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS USING HAZARD AND SOCIODEMOGRAPHIC DATA TO IDENTIFY AREAS AND POPULATIONS THAT ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO DISASTER EVENTS; 2) FACILITATION OF THE EXTREME EVENT GAME, A NATURAL DISASTER SIMULATION DEVELOPED BY THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES, WITH SELECT COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND FACILITATOR TRAINING; 3) COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND PLAN INTEGRATION ON DISASTER PREPAREDNESS, INCLUDING DEVELOPMENT OF RESOURCE CHECKLISTS, BEST PRACTICES FOR EVACUATION PLANS, AND IMPROVING UPTAKE OF EMERGENC

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT ENTAILS THE ORGANIZATION OF TWO OIL SPILL PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR THE MASHPEE WAMPANOAG TRIBE FIRST LIGHT AQUACULTURE FARM AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN OIL SPILL PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE MANUAL AND COMMUNICATIONS AND COORDINATION PLAN.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MASHPEE WAMPANOAG TRIBE DISASTER RESPONSE PLAN AND TRAINING PROGRAM TO HELP THE TRIBE PREPARE FOR AN OIL SPILL AND THE IMPACTS THAT WOULD HAVE ON THE TRIBE'S FIRST LIGHT AQUACULTURE FARM. DEVELOPMENT OF THIS PLAN WOULD ALSO INCLUDE PURCHASING AND POSITIONING OF NEEDED EQUIPMENT, TRAINING OF KEY PERSONNEL AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS.    EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DEVELOPMENT OF A DISASTER RESPONSE PLAN, EQUIPMENT PURCHASES AND TRAINING WOULD RESULT IN A PREPARED COMMUNITY READY TO RESPOND TO AN OIL SPILL AND STRENGTHENED CROSS-AGENCY AND REGIONAL CONNECTIONS THAT WOULD BE INTEGRAL TO A SUCCESSFUL RESPONSE TO MITIGATE AN OIL SPILL'S IMPACT. PURPOSE: THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO DEVELOP A STAKEHOLDER DATABASE AND OUTREACH STRATEGY, EVALUATE PERCEPTIONS OF FLOATING OFFSHORE WIND AMONG ONSHORE, USE MENTAL MODELS TO IDENTIFY ADAPTIVE CAPACITY OF VARIOUS COMMUNITIES TO OFFSHORE WIND, AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR COEXISTENCE OF FLOATING WIND AND VARIOUS OCEAN USE ACTIVITIES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A MEDIA ANALYSIS, ASSET MAPPING WORKSHOP WILL BE CONDUCTED. OFFSHORE WIND SCENARIOS WILL BE GENERATED AND THOSE WILL BE COUPLED WITH STAKEHOLDER INTERVIEWS TO UNDERSTAND THE MAJOR THEMES, CONCERNS AND ATTITUDES TOWARDS FLOATING OFFSHORE WIND. LASTLY, A STANDARDIZED SURVEY TOOL AND IN-DEPTH INTERVIEWS WILL BE CONDUCTED. PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS INSTITUTIONAL AWARD AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO FACILITATE THE EXPANSION OF THE PISASC SCHOLARS PROGRAM. THIS IS A PARTNERSHIP EFFORT BETWEEN HAWAII SEA GRANT AND USGS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ALL OF THE PROJECTS IDENTIFIED OVER THIS TIME PERIOD WILL FURTHER THE MISSION AND VISION OF PI-CASC TO DELIVER SCIENCE AND TO BUILD WORKFORCE CAPACITY TO HELP FISH, WILDLIFE, WATER, LAND, AND PEOPLE ADAPT TO A CHANGING CLIMATE. SPECIFICALLY, THIS IAA SEEKS TO SUPPORT THE EXPANSION OF THE CURRENT PI-CASC GRADUATE SCHOLARS PROGRAM AND TECHNICAL CAPACITY IN SUPPORT OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY, TECH TRANSFER, DATABASE CAPACITY, AND COMMUNICATIONS DELIVERY NEEDS FOR ALL FUNCTIONAL AREAS OF PI-CASC (RESEARCH, COMMUNICATIONS, EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND ADMINISTRATION). ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES: OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE NEW AND EXPANDED STUDENT-BASED PROJECTS THAT ADVANCE THE SHARED GOALS OF HAWAII SEA GRANT AND PISASC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT

PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT IS A SCOPING STUDY TO TEST A PROOF OF CONCEPT THAT HIGH QUALITY, FINE-SCALE AGGREGATE SPATIAL TEMPORAL REPRESENTATIONS OF THE MAINE LOBSTER FISHERY CAN BE GENERATED FROM INDIVIDUAL FISHERMAN'S PERSONAL COMPUTER (PC)-BASED NAVIGATION AND PLOTTER DATA, ASSURE THAT THE PROOF OF CONCEPT ADDRESSES THE PROPRIETARY NATURE OF THE INDIVIDUAL FISHERMAN'S DATA CONTRIBUTIONS, AND DEVELOP PRODUCT SPECIFICATIONS AND INITIAL SAMPLE PRODUCTS THAT WILL MEET THE NEEDS OF FISHERIES MANAGEMENT AND MARINE SPATIAL PLANNING.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: DIFFERENT PC CHART PLOTTER/NAVIGATION SYSTEM FORMATS WILL BE ASSESSED AND DATA COLLECTED FROM A SET OF VOLUNTEER LOBSTERMEN, WHOSE DATA WILL BE ANONYMIZED, AND WITH WHOM DATA PRODUCT MODELS WILL BE COLLABORATIVELY DEVELOPED AND EVALUATED.    EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A STANDARDIZED PROCEDURE FOR CONSTRUCTING ACCURATE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL REPRESENTATIONS OF THE MAINE LOBSTER FISHERY USING THE DATA AND KNOWLEDGE OF INDIVIDUAL FISHERMEN WILL

PURPOSE: TO DEVELOP A MAPPING TOOL THAT CAN BE USED IN THE MARINE SPATIAL PLANNING PROCESS IN THE NORTHEAST UNITED STATES TO HIGHLIGHT POTENTIAL CONFLICTS AS WELL AS SYNERGIES THAT MAY EXIST BETWEEN OFFSHORE WIND FARM DEVELOPERS, COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERS, AQUACULTURE FARMERS, AND WAVE ENERGY DEVELOPERS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A SIMULATION MODEL WILL BE BUILT AND THEN USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH A GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS)-BASED MODEL THAT SYNTHESIZES AVAILABLE DATASETS AND INCORPORATES BASIC MULTI-CRITERIA DECISION ANALYSIS TO DEVELOP A MAPPING TOOL THAT WILL ENABLE USERS TO EXPLORE AND FIND SUITABLE OFFSHORE AREAS OF THE NORTHEAST FOR DEVELOPMENT.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A TOOL THAT FACILITATES THE INTEGRATION OF MULTIPLE OCEAN USES IN THE SAME AREA WILL INCREASE INFORMATION AVAILABLE FOR DECISION-MAKING AND ENABLE SYMBIOSIS BETWEEN RENEWABLE ENERGY AND FOOD SYSTEMS, AND THE ECONOMIC EFFICIENCIES THAT COME WITH THIS SYMBIOSIS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO COMMUNITY RESI

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INVESTIGATE THE COMMUNICATION AND ENGAGEMENT STRATEGIES USED TO SHARE INFORMATION ABOUT PROPOSED OFFSHORE WIND DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS WITH IMPACTED COMMUNITIES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  CONTENT ANALYSIS OF PUBLIC-FACING MESSAGING, QUALITATIVE INTERVIEWS, A SOCIAL NETWORK ANALYSIS, AND A QUANTITATIVE SURVEY WILL BE CONDUCTED IN THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION TO MANAGERS AND SCHOLARS ON HOW SUCH PROJECTS ARE BEING COMMUNICATED, WHAT THE ROLE AND INFLUENCE OF THE KEY MESSENGERS ARE, AND WHAT MESSAGING AND ENGAGEMENT STRATEGIES ARE MOST EFFECTIVE FOR INCLUSIVE ENGAGEMENT ON CURRENT AND FUTURE PROJECTS.    INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: MESSENGERS, MANAGERS, RESEARCHERS, DEVELOPERS, AND COASTAL STAKEHOLDERS  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

PURPOSE: TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF BOTH THE RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT COMMUNITIES REGARDING  THE PROCEDURAL, DISTRIBUTIVE, AND RECOGNITIONAL JUSTICE DIMENSIONS OF OFFSHORE WIND DECISION-MAKING.        ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A MIXED-METHODS BASELINE ASSESSMENT, COMPRISING INTERVIEWS AND A SURVEY, OF FIVE SETTLER COMMUNITIES IN THE SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND REGION AS WELL AS SEVEN TRIBAL NATIONS LOCATED NEAR THESE COMMUNITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED. COMMUNITY CONCERNS AND RESEARCH QUESTIONS REGARDING PROCEDURAL, DISTRIBUTIVE, AND RECOGNITIONAL JUSTICE DIMENSIONS OF SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND OFFSHORE WIND PROJECTS WILL BE IDENTIFIED, QUANTITATIVELY ASSESSED, AND DIFFERENCES IN ATTITUDES WITHIN AND AMONG SETTLER AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES WILL BE EXAMINED  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A MORE ROBUST BODY OF SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH TO INFORM CURRENT AND FUTURE OFFSHORE WIND PROJECTS, INCLUDING THE CREATION OF BASELINE DATA AND COMPARATIVE CASE STUDIES TO INFORM DECISION-MAKING FOR TRIBAL NATIONS, FEDERAL AND S

PURPOSE: OUR GOAL IS TO DEVELOP AND PILOT ENGAGEMENT METHODS AND PRACTICES IN DOWNEAST MAINE THAT SUPPORT ROBUST PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN OCEAN RENEWABLE ENERGY (ORE) DECISION MAKING.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  USING PARTICIPATORY METHODS INVOLVING INTERVIEWS, FOCUS GROUPS, SURVEYS AND GEOSPATIAL MAPS THE PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY THE VALUES AND BELIEFS THAT INFLUENCE SOCIAL ACCEPTANCE OF ORE TO DETERMINE THE 'PLACE-TECHNOLOGY FIT' FOR THREE COMMUNITIES IN DOWNEAST MAINE RESULTING IN A COMMUNITY ORE TOOLKIT THAT CAN BE USED IN COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE NORTHEASTERN US AND BEYOND.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: BY PILOTING THE COMMUNITY ORE TOOLKIT, WE WILL DEVELOP A MORE REPRESENTATIVE AND DIVERSE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW VALUES AND BELIEFS INFLUENCE PEOPLE'S RESPONSES TO ORE, AND WHAT GOVERNMENTS, DEVELOPERS, AND SUPPORTERS CAN DO TO SUPPORT COMMUNITIES IN THE RENEWABLE ENERGY TRANSITION. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS ESPECIALLY FOCUSED ON STAKEHOLDERS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED OR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES,

PURPOSE: THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. CONGRESS IN 1966 (AMENDED IN 2008, PUBLIC LAW 110-394) TO BE A HIGHLY LEVERAGED FEDERAL AND STATE PARTNERSHIP TO HARNESS THE INTELLECTUAL CAPACITY OF THE NATIONS UNIVERSITIES AND RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS TO SOLVE PROBLEMS AND GENERATE OPPORTUNITIES IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES. FOR OVER 50 YEARS, THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM HAS SUPPORTED COASTAL AND GREAT LAKES COMMUNITIES THROUGH RESEARCH, EXTENSION AND EDUCATION. SEA GRANT'S MISSION IS TO ENHANCE THE PRACTICAL USE AND CONSERVATION OF COASTAL, MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES IN ORDER TO CREATE A SUSTAINABLE ECONOMY AND ENVIRONMENT.   THIS GRANT IS THE VEHICLE THROUGH WHICH MIT SEA GRANT LAYS OUT ITS PLAN TO IMPLEMENT THE GOALS LAID OUT IN IN THEIR FY2018-23 STRATEGIC PLAN, WHICH CAN BE FOUND AT: HTTPS://SEAGRANT.NOAA.GOV/INSIDESEAGRANT/PLANNING  IN ADDITION TO REQUIRED GRANT PROGRESS REPORTING, THE RECIPIENT WILL REPORT DEFINED MEASURES AND METRICS AS

PURPOSE:  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE PACIFIC REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE (PACIFIC RISCC) MANAGEMENT BY SUPPORTING A NEW HIRE TO SUPPORT SUPPORT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO DECREASE THE THREAT TO ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND COMMUNITIES POSED BY THE INTERACTION OF CLIMATE CHANGE WITH INVASIVE, NON-NATIVE SPECIES WITHIN INTERIOR REGION 12, THE PACIFIC REGION COVERED BY BOTH SA AND PI-CASC.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THE TWO-YEAR POSITION IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE PACIFIC RISCC MANAGEMENT NETWORK IN THE FORM OF AN INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE PROGRAM SPECIALIST. IT IS ANTICIPATED THIS INDIVIDUAL WILL INTERFACE CLOSELY WITH SA STAFF AND PARTNERS, SUPPORTING A MORE HOLISTIC CONTEXT TO THE PACIFIC RISCC DEVELOPMENT.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:  THE COORDINATOR WILL PROVIDE COORDINATION, DEVELOP MANAGEMENT RELEVANT PRODUCTS, AND CREATE RESOURCES FOR RESEARCHERS.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.
