IN ADDITION TO REQUIRED GRANT PROGRESS REPORTING, THE RECIPIENT WILL REPORT DEFINED MEASURES AND METRICS AS WELL AS SUCCESS STORIES ANNUALLY AND WILL BE EVALUATED ON PERFORMANCE DURING A SITE REVIEW EXPECTED IN 2024 OR 2025.

ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: EACH UNIVERSITY-BASED SEA GRANT PROGRAM CONTRIBUTES TO THE NATIONAL FOCUS AREAS AND GOALS, AND WHOI SEA GRANT IS NO DIFFERENT, ALIGNING THEIR FOCUS AREAS WITH THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT STRATEGIC PLAN'S FOCUS AREAS OF: HEALTHY COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS, SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES AND AQUACULTURE, RESILIENT COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIES, AND ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT. ACTIVITIES WITHIN EACH OF THESE FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE RESEARCH, EXTENSION AND EDUCATIONAL PROJECTS THAT AIM TO FURTHER THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM'S STATED MISSION. 

EXPECTED OUTCOMES: NOAA PROVIDES FUNDING TO SEA GRANT INSTITUTIONS TO INCREASE THE UNDERSTANDING, ASSESSMENT, DEVELOPMENT, MANAGEMENT, UTILIZATION, AND CONSERVATION OF THE NATION'S OCEAN, COASTAL, AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES. THESE IMPORTANT EFFORTS PROMOTE A STRONG EDUCATIONAL BASE, RESPONSIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING ACTIVITIES, BROAD AND PROMPT DISSEMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNIQUES, AND MULTIDISCIPLINARY APPROACHES TO ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS, IN ACCORDANCE WITH 33 U.S.C.   1121(B). SPECIFIC OUTCOMES IDENTIFIED BY THE RECIPIENT INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO:

STAKEHOLDERS ARE PROVIDED WITH LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES AND RESOURCES THAT SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE USE OF WATERSHED, COASTAL, AND MARINE RESOURCES.

NATURAL RESOURCE AND EMERGENCY MANAGERS, AS WELL AS BUILDING OFFICIALS,  UNDERSTAND, SYNTHESIZE, AND APPLY BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE AND INFORMATION TO IMPROVE COASTAL RESILIENCY.

COASTAL COMMUNITIES CAN ACCESS AND UNDERSTAND LONG-TERM MONITORING DATA AND LEADING EDGE RESEARCH TO IMPROVE COASTAL DECISION-MAKING.

DIVERSE MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY ARE AWARE OF CHANGING CLIMATIC, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND USE THIS INFORMATION TO IMPROVE COASTAL RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABILITY.

SUPPORT AND EDUCATE COMMUNITIES IN THEIR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE COASTAL RESILIENCE THROUGH FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT.

COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS ENGAGE WITH AND ASSIST THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY WITH MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING PRODUCTION AND ADAPTING TO CHANGING CONDITIONS

COMMUNITIES ARE PROVIDED WITH UNBIASED INFORMATION ON LOCAL SEAFOOD, HOW IT IS HARVESTED AND GROWN, AND ITS HEALTH BENEFITS.

COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES THAT SERVE STUDENTS FROM UNDERSERVED AND UNDERREPRESENTED POPULATIONS ARE BETTER REPRESENTED IN WHSG'S FUNDED RESEARCH PORTFOLIO.

INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: RESIDENTS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND DECISION-MAKERS OF THE STATE OF MASSACHUSETTS AS WELL AS THROUGHOUT THE NORTHEAST REGION.

SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MASSACHUSETTS WHO SUCCESSFULLY COMPETED FOR FUNDING FOLLOWING THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM'S COMPETITION POLICY. ADDITIONALLY, FUNDING MAY BE SUB-AWARDED FOR EXTENSION OR EDUCATION WORK.

PURPOSE:  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT A STRATEGIC RESILIENCE PLANNING PROCESS FOR COMMUNITIES IN LOUISIANA IMPACTED BY RECENT HURRICANES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  EIGHT COMMUNITIES WILL BE IDENTIFIED TO PARTICIPATE IN A MULTI-DAY DESIGN WORKSHOP FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS AND SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS TO DEVELOP PRIORITY PROJECTS RELATED TO DISASTER RECOVERY AND LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY AND RESILIENCE FOR INCLUSION IN STRATEGIC PRIORITY PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLANS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: EIGHT LOUISIANA COMMUNITIES WILL HAVE TOOLS AND INFORMATION FOR ENHANCING RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABILITY IN THEIR POST-DISASTER RECOVERY/PRE-DISASTER PLANNING. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:  OFFICIALS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF PARTICIPATING COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY RECENT HURRICANES IN LOUISIANA. THE KNAUSS FELLOWSHIP PROVIDES A ONE-YEAR EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN AN EXECUTIVE OR LEGISLATIVE BRANCH OFFICE WHICH WILL: 1) EXPAND THE STUDENT'S EXPERIENCE WITH, AND KNOWLEDGE OF, THE POLICY-MAKING PROCESS WITHIN FEDERAL AGENCIES AND CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEALING WITH MARINE AND COASTAL ISSUES; AND 2) ALLOW THE STUDENT TO CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE GAINED IN ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE INFORMATIONAL FEEDBACK TO PROGRAMS, THUS ASSISTING IN THE STUDENT'S LONG-TERM CAREER AND EDUCATIONAL GOALS.  PROVIDE PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON POLICY-MAKING TRAINING ON MARINE AND GREAT LAKES RESOURCES TO THE GRADUATE STUDENT WITH HOSTS IN THE LEGISLATIVE AND EXECUTIVE BRANCHES OF GOVERNMENT IN THE WASHINGTON, D.C. AREA.  THE YEAR SPENT AS A KNAUSS FELLOW AUGMENTS THE STUDENT'S EDUCATION BY PROVIDING PRACTICAL TRAINING AND UNDERSTANDING OF HOW MARINE ISSUES ARE HANDLED AT THE FEDERAL LEVEL.  THIS FELLOWSHIP WILL BENEFIT THE STUDENT, AS WELL AS CONTRIBUTE TO THE POOL OF YOUNG AND EXPERIENCED GRADUATES WITH

THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A NATIONAL CLIMATE EXTENSION SERVICES (NCES) LIAISON WHO WILL BRING TOGETHER THE UNIQUE CAPABILITIES OF NOAA SEA GRANT IN SYNERGISTIC PARTNERSHIP WITH THE USGS CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS (CASC) TO FACILITATE INTEGRATION OF FEDERALLY FUNDED RESEARCH AND END-USER NEEDS FOCUSED ON CLIMATE ADAPTATION. THE NCES LIAISON WILL INCREASE CONNECTIVITY AND SYNERGISTIC OUTCOMES FOR AND BETWEEN THE SEA GRANT AND CASC NETWORKS, WITH A FOCUS ON LEVERAGING THE CAPACITY OF SEA GRANTS MORE THAN 500 EXTENSION SPECIALISTS WORKING ON THE GROUND ACROSS ALL OF THE U.S. COASTAL AND GREAT LAKES STATES, WITH THE REGIONALLY FOCUSED NATIONAL CAPACITY OF THE CASC RESEARCH-MANAGEMENT ENTERPRISE. WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF THIS PARTNERSHIP, TOGETHER WITH ADDITIONAL FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL PARTNERS, THE NCES LIAISON WILL COORDINATE EXPERTISE AND CONTRIBUTE TO DEVELOPMENT OF CUTTING-EDGE SCIENTIFIC AND MANAGEMENT COLLABORATIONS. FURTHER, THESE PARTNERSHIPS WILL ENHANCE DATA AND PRODUCT S

NEW JERSEY SEA GRANT (NJSG) WILL ADVANCE INNOVATIVE GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE (GI) AND LOW IMPACT DEVELOPMENT (LID) PLANNING AND TECHNIQUES FOR MITIGATING RUNOFF AND POLLUTION IMPACTS ON FRESHWATER AND OTHER COASTAL SYSTEMS IN THE UNITED STATES. COMPONENT I OF THE PROJECT WILL PRIORITIZE GI AND LID RESEARCH NEEDS AND DELINEATE THE ROLES OF AND STRATEGIES FOR THE SEA GRANT NETWORK IN COLLABORATION WITH AGENCIES AND OTHER PARTNERS. COMPONENT II IS A COMPETITIVE RESEARCH FUNDING PROGRAM THAT WILL IMPLEMENT UP TO THREE PROJECTS IN METROPOLITAN AREAS OF THE MID-ATLANTIC SEA GRANT REGION (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, DELAWARE, PENNSYLVANIA, MARYLAND, VIRGINIA, AND NORTH CAROLINA). THE FINDINGS FROM THE IMPLEMENTED RESEARCH PROJECTS AND THE INPUTS THROUGH BROADER STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO A STRATEGIC DOCUMENT AND A BEST PRACTICE MANUAL FOR THE SEA GRANT NETWORK TO MAXIMIZE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF FUTURE GI AND LID EFFORTS.
CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN: DEFINING A STRATEGIC ROLE FOR SEA GRANT

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR COMMUNITIES IN THE SOUTHEAST TO BE MORE RISK AWARE AND CAPABLE OF RESPONDING TO SEVERE WEATHER EVENTS THROUGH ACTIVE ENGAGEMENT AND CO-CREATION OF KNOWLEDGE THAT IS BASED ON VORTEX-SE RESEARCH (BOTH PHYSICAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCE). THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO CONTINUE TO BUILD PARTNERS IN THE REGION AND IDENTIFY THEIR PRIORITIES RELATED TO SUPPORTING A TORNADO-RELATED EXTENSION PROGRAM; TO UNDERSTAND A SUBSET OF TARGET AUDIENCE NEEDS AND RECENT RESEARCH FINDINGS THAT CAN CONTINUE TO INFORM A TORNADO-RELATED EXTENSION PROGRAM; AND TO IMPLEMENT THE GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND MODEL FRAMEWORK FOUND IN THE EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND ENGAGEMENT (EOE) PLAN DEVELOPED AS PART OF THE PILOT PHASE TO IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE OF VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES TO SEVERE WEATHER.
COORDINATED OCEAN ENERGY EXPERTISE FOR NORTHEAST COASTAL STAKEHOLDERS: MAINE

THIS PROJECT WILL CARRY OUT THEORETICALLY RIGOROUS AND EMPIRICALLY RELIABLE ANALYSIS OF THE ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC EFFECTS ON RECREATIONAL FISHERIES OF CHANGES IN THE NUMBER AND COMPOSITION OF OIL AND GAS RIGS ON THE GULF OF MEXICO OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF (GOM OCS) FOR THE PURPOSE OF INFORMING A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT WILL ALLOW STAKEHOLDERS AND POLICY MAKERS TO PREDICT THE CONSEQUENCES OF SPECIFIC CHANGES IN THE COMPOSITION OF THE RIGS IN THE GULF ON SPECIES ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION, AND RECREATIONAL ANGLERS SATISFACTION AND SUBSEQUENT DEMAND.

POPULATION LEVELS OF AMERICAN LOBSTER (HOMARUS AMERICANUS) ARE AT TIME SERIES HIGHS, HOWEVER, YOUNG OF THE YEAR (YOY) RECRUITMENT THROUGHOUT THE GULF OF MAINE (GOM) HAS REMAINED AT LOW LEVELS SINCE 2012. WHILE THERE ARE SIGNS OF DECLINES IN SMALL SIZE CLASSES IN SOUTHWESTERN GOM BASED ON DATA FROM THE COASTWIDE VENTLESS TRAP SURVEY (VTS), AREAS FARTHER TO THE NORTHEAST DO NOT SHOW SIGNS OF DECLINE (ASMFC 2020). THE GOM IS WARMING AT AN UNPRECEDENTED RATE (MILLS ET AL. 2013, PERSHING ET AL. 2015), WHICH MAY BE A CONFOUNDING FACTOR IN INTERPRETING VTS INDICES, BECAUSE OF THE STRONG CORRELATION BETWEEN WATER TEMPERATURE AND TRAP CATCH AT ALL SIZE CLASSES (MCLEESE & WILDER 1958, PALOHEIMO 1963, ASMFC 2020). TO COMPOUND THIS ISSUE, WHILE THE AMERICAN LOBSTER SETTLEMENT SURVEY IS EFFECTIVE AT SAMPLING YOY AND ONE-YEAR OLDS (6-17MM IN CARAPACE LENGTH (CL)), AND THE VTS SAMPLES OLDER JUVENILES (>50MM CL), THERE IS CURRENTLY NO EFFECTIVE METHOD FOR SAMPLING EARLY BENTHIC PHASE (EBP)

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO SUPPORT THE CT SHELLFISH SECTOR FROM THE CONSEQUENCES OF THE COVID 19 PANDEMIC, AND TO POSITION IT TO BE MORE RESILIENT IN THE FUTURE. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL EVALUATE THE FEASIBILITY OF ENGAGING THE SHELLFISH AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY IN MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING THE PRODUCTIVITY OF NATURAL SHELLFISH BEDS FOR ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND QUANTIFY THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF DIFFERENT INTERVENTIONS, INDIVIDUALLY AND COMBINED, THAT WILL INFORM LONGER-TERM MANAGEMENT APPROACHES. IN ADDITION, THE FEASIBILITY OF A SHELL RECYCLING PROGRAM FOR LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY VIA PROCUREMENT OF SHELL AS SUBSTRATE FOR SHELLFISH RECRUITMENT THROUGH A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT AND ASSOCIATED SOCIOECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH WILL BE DETERMINED. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO: ENGAGE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY MEMBERS TO RESTORE SILTED NATURAL BEDS BY BRINGING OYSTER SHELLS ON THE SURFACE AS SUBSTRATE FOR OYSTER LARVAE SETTLEMENT; TRANSPLANT SHELL AS SUBSTRATE AND OVERSIZED OYSTERS AS BROODSTOCK ON NATURAL BEDS; ASSESS OYSTER RECRUITMENT SUCCESS ON BEDS FOLLOWING DIFFERENT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES; ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF USING SHELL RECYCLING PROGRAMS FOR LONGER-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF BEDS; AND COMMUNICATE RESULTS ACROSS STAKEHOLDER GROUPS INCLUDING INDUSTRY, REGULATORS, POLICY MAKERS AND FUNDING AGENCIES.

DESPITE THE FACT THAT NUMEROUS STUDIES HAVE EXAMINED WATER CHEMISTRY IN OFFSHORE AREAS WHERE HYPOXIA IS FREQUENT, TEMPORAL AND GEOGRAPHIC TRENDS IN SALINITY, CARBONATE CHEMISTRY, AND OTHER WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS IN NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO (GOM) COASTAL AREAS WHERE OYSTER HATCHERIES WOULD DRAW WATER ARE UNKNOWN. MOREOVER, THE MANNER IN WHICH SALINITY, CARBONATE CHEMISTRY, AND OTHER WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS INTERACT AND HOW THAT INTERACTION MAY CORRELATE WITH HATCHERY PRODUCTION IN THE NORTHERN GOM IS UNKNOWN. BECAUSE THE GOM REGION REQUIRES AN INCREASE IN HATCHERY CAPACITY AND TECHNOLOGIES TO MAINTAIN AND EXPAND THE OYSTER INDUSTRY, TAKE ADVANTAGE OF INCREASING DEMAND FOR LOCALLY PRODUCED SEAFOOD, AND EXPAND ECONOMIC BENEFITS IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES, THERE IS A STRONG NEED TO CHARACTERIZE THE DYNAMICS OF BRACKISH WATER CARBONATE CHEMISTRY ALONG NORTHERN GOM COAST INCLUDING BOTH MISSISSIPPI RIVER INFLUENCED COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS AND OTHER ESTUARINE ENVIRONMENTS ESPECIALLY DURING THE SEAS

FOR THIS RESEARCH, THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON, NOAA, AND BAYWATER SHELLFISH WILL COLLABORATE TO INTEGRATE OCEANOGRAPHIC MEASUREMENTS, FIELD WORK, AND LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS TO EXAMINE THE PHYSIOLOGICAL TOLERANCE AND SURVIVAL OF DIPLOID AND TRIPLOID CRASSOSTREA GIGAS (PACIFIC OYSTER) UNDER MULTIPLE STRESSORS. WHEN COMBINED WITH ECONOMIC INFORMATION AND SUMMARIZED IN A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL, OUR RESULTS WILL HELP SHELLFISH GROWERS BALANCE THE RISKS AND BENEFITS OF PLANTING TRIPLOID OYSTERS (THAT ARE MARKETABLE IN SUMMER) AGAINST THE POTENTIALLY HIGHER MORTALITY OF TRIPLOIDS COMPARED TO DIPLOIDS AS A FUNCTION OF THE MULTI-STRESSOR ENVIRONMENT.

THE POTENTIAL HIGHER MORTALITY ASSOCIATED WITH TRIPLOIDS CREATES A RISK ASSESSMENT CHALLENGE FOR GROWERS. GROWERS MUST CHOOSE WHETHER TO PLANT DIPLOIDS, WHICH HAVE A LOWER MORTALITY, BUT ARE UNMARKETABLE IN THE SUMMER OR PLANT TRIPLOIDS, WHICH CAN BE SOLD YEAR-ROUND, BUT MAY DIE BEFORE THEY CAN BE HARVESTED. WE PLAN TO DEVELOP A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT WILL ALLOW GROWERS TO QUANTITATIVELY ASSESS WHICH PLOIDY IS THE BETTER OPTION FOR A PARTICULAR SITE GIVEN THE EFFECT OF MULTIPLE STRESSORS. THE TOOL COULD BE APPLIED BOTH IN THE CURRENT SEASON FOR REAL-TIME DECISIONS AND BE USED AS PART OF A FORWARD-LOOKING ASSESSMENT TO IMPROVE CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR THE SHELLFISH INDUSTRY IN WASHINGTON STATE.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES:
1. EXAMINE HOW THE NATURAL VARIABILITY OF TEMPERATURE, PH, AND DISSOLVED OXYGEN INFLUENCES THE SURVIVAL, GAMETOGENESIS AND PHYSIOLOGY OF DIPLOID AND TRIPLOID OYSTERS IN FARM SETTINGS.
2. QUANTIFY THE EFFECTS OF PH, TEMPERATURE AND OXYGEN ON THE PHYSIOLOGICAL PERFORMANCE OF ADULT C. GIGAS IN A LABORATORY SETTING USING SINGLE AND MULTIPLE STRESSOR EXPERIMENTS.
3. DEVELOP A DECISION TOOL FOR GROWERS TO EVALUATE THE LIKELY IMPACTS OF MULTIPLE STRESSORS ON TRIPLOID AND DIPLOID OYSTERS IN PUGET SOUND, WASHINGTON.

SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES REEF FISHERIES ARE SOME OF THE MOST COMMERCIALLY VALUABLE AND RECREATIONALLY POPULAR IN THE COUNTRY. ACROSS THESE FISHERIES, A SPECIOSE ASSEMBLAGE IS TARGETED BY A DIVERSE AND GEOGRAPHICALLY VARIABLE GROUP OF STAKEHOLDERS WHO COLLECTIVELY POSSESS A WEALTH OF LOCAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM YEARS ON THE WATER. RECENTLY, THE RESULTS OF FEDERAL STOCK ASSESSMENTS FOR MANY REEF FISHES HAVE BEEN AT ODDS WITH THE ON-THE-WATER OBSERVATIONS OF COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERMEN, CREATING A DISCONNECT THAT ERODES STAKEHOLDER FAITH IN THE CREDIBILITY OF SCIENTIFIC FINDINGS. BROADLY SPEAKING, THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED REGIONAL COLLABORATIVE IS TO BUILD UPON THE CONVENTIONAL UNIDIRECTIONAL FLOW OF INFORMATION (I.E., FROM RESEARCH TO MANAGEMENT TO STAKEHOLDER) BY WORKING DIRECTLY WITH STAKEHOLDERS ON A CONSISTENT BASIS TO IDENTIFY PRESSING RESEARCH NEEDS AND COMMUNICATE THOSE NEEDS TO THE SCIENTIFIC AND MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY (I.E., FROM STAKEHOLDER TO RESEARC

THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A LEARNING NETWORK TO FACILITATE PEER-TO-PEER LEARNING AROUND BEST PRACTICES AND LESSONS LEARNED FROM CURRENT CITIZEN MONITORING AND OUTREACH EFFORTS RELATED TO SHORELINE FLOODING AND EROSION THROUGHOUT THE NE REGION.
